The current committee has not been able to consider things in a non-partisan way, as it could prior to this particular investigation being set up. Altogether, the performance of this election rorts committee has been politically `loaded' and biased. I believe the government should announce that this committee reference has been a total political failure. It has been a political stunt from the beginning, and it should be wound up.

The idiocy—and that is the only word I can use to describe it—of some of the submissions in support of the government has led to one fact that I think has been unreported to the wider Australian public, and that occurs in a major appendix to the Liberal Party submission to this election rorts committee. That appendix was some 2,700 pages long, and each one of those pages contained 60 names. Who were those people mentioned on those 2,700 pages? These were people suggested by the official Liberal Party submission as perhaps being involved in election rorts in Queensland. They were ordinary Queenslanders whose names appeared at one address, with more than four different names at that address. The fact that they might have been nursing homes or the fact that there might have been students living together were good reasons for there being different names at that one address, and to denigrate people who have different names and to suggest that they were rorting the electoral roll is disgraceful. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Much has been said in recent weeks about issues in regional Australia. In October 1999, the Deputy Prime Minister's great initiative known as the Regional Australia Summit brought together people from all over Australia to look at the issues which, in a rather disjointed way, the media are endeavouring to address at the moment. I thought it would be useful today to remind the House and regional Australia of some of the achievements of this government and the focus that it brings to regional Australia.

speech.para: Some of the priorities and areas for change were in community empowerment—that is, creating regional communities with a greater capacity to have a bottom-up approach rather than this top-down, rather patronising approach that our opponents would insist should apply in regional Australia. An initiative should be sufficiently flexible to cater for the particular circumstances and needs of various regional, rural and remote communities. Another very important strategic area is the economic and business development in regional communities. That includes investing in regional infrastructure, fostering business innovation and rural industries in regional Australia and encouraging sustainable natural resource management—very much a focus particularly since the launch of the Natural Heritage Trust some four years ago. Another issue that is of great importance to regional communities is the matter of equity in the delivery of services. That includes improving education and training, improving health outcomes—and that is through the provision of better professional advice and support—improving communications and improving family services.

One initiative that has flowed out of the Regional Australia Summit addressing those general strategic areas was a clear and cooperative approach, despite all the rhetoric, for improving services to people living in regional Australia. That has already been agreed to by regional development ministers from the states and territories, local government and the Commonwealth. The Foundation for Rural and Regional Renewal, announced at the summit, finalised their first round of funding in August 2000. The $240 million for the Stronger Families and Communities Strategies that was announced in April 2000 directly addressed a number of summit recommendations. Health was a key theme featured as a major budget item, with an allocation of $562 million. The Community Development Employment Program, with another 1,500 extra participant places, provided new employment opportunities for indigenous people in remote and isolated communities. A very important extension, a $309 million extension, of the Agriculture—Advancing Australia package has been provided, including a $167.5 million program, Skilling Farmers for the Future. And, of course, a very important historic announcement late last year was the $700 million National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality. That amount is to be matched by the states, totalling an allocation of $1.4 billion over the next decade.

Much is made of how tough it is in `the bush', as it is known. I prefer to call that part of Australia `the regions'. Coming from the regional areas of Australia, I do not take that easily to the terminology `the bush'. It is, to many people, a slight denigration of those of us who live out there. Therefore, to those of us who live in regional Australia, it is very important that the summit has addressed many of these issues.

I could add to those that I mentioned before the $90 million Regional Solutions program, which really acknowledges that it is very important to have a locally focused solution and that one solution does not fit all. Of course, as for that infrastructure program of the government, it would be remiss of me not to recall the $1.6 billion boost to the national road network. There has been quite a furphy around the $2.9 billion that allegedly had not been spent by the previous government and by this government because of some technicality in the legislation, but never before in my time in this place—and not, I think, for at least a couple of decades—has there been an allocation along the lines of that $1.6 billion to the nation's road network.

Sustainable natural resource management is part of all this. I have mentioned the water and salinity quality program, the largest ever announced in this country and very important to these issues. Our government is supporting the Natural Heritage Trust, which is investing $1.5 billion over six years, with $700 million already approved—believe it or not—in 6,400 projects which address issues like biodiversity, conservation and sustainable agriculture in an integrated manner. We have the Cape York Natural Heritage Trust Plan, which has provided up to $40 million to protect the outstanding natural and cultural values of Cape York. The $264 million renewable remote power generation program, which began in July 2000, provides a rebate of up to 50 per cent of the capital cost of converting diesel based remote off-grid electricity supplies to renewable energy technologies. The greenhouse gas abatement program is providing $400 million over the next three years.

Equity of services in regional committees is essential. It sends a message to regional Australia that we are as good as anyone else and that we expect to be treated as well as anyone else. To acknowledge that, the government has brought in, through policy change, better access to the youth allowance, a family assets test to 75 per cent and increased allowances for the isolated children's scheme and Abstudy. It has continued to fund the country areas program and increased incentives for employers to help apprentices gain higher skill levels. I have mentioned Skilling Farmers for the Future under Farmbis for property management planning. Networking the Nation is very important. We have some way to go there, but there has simply never been a greater investment by any government in communications infrastructure.

Encouragement for rural doctors is very important and it is worth going through where the government is trying to improve health outcomes: increasing the number of new general practitioner registrars, $100 million; increasing the range of allied health services, $50 million; providing rural specialists through an outreach program, almost $50 million; and providing work force support for rural general practitioners, $10 million. New clinical schools is a big and very long-term visionary project by this government and this minister: $117.6 million goes to nine clinical schools, building on the successful departments of rural health established by this government three or four years ago. We could go on: providing scholarships under the RAMUS scheme, the Regional Health Service program, $70 million; pharmacy services, et cetera. A very important one I should not miss is ensuring appropriate aged care facilities in regional Australia—$30.8 million. Considering that our opponents spent $10 million for the whole of Australia in their last term of office, I think that shows the generosity of this government.

In conclusion, I simply remind the House and particularly regional Australians that this government has given very solid and very strong consideration to regional Australia. Let us remember that it inherited high interest rates and big debts. It has got on top of that, it has the Charter of Budget Honesty, it is strongly in control of the Treasury and now it is able to put into place in regional Australia those sorts of programs that will serve regional Australia well in the future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On 13 December last year, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services announced, `The government has decided to make Bankstown airport available as an overflow airport for Sydney,' and also that the operator of Bankstown airport `will be encouraged to extend the main runway so it can handle jet aircraft'. That was a declaration of war to the people of south-western Sydney. It was a declaration that drew an immediate response from the surrounding councils. Bankstown, Liverpool, Canterbury and Fairfield councils pledged to fight the proposal and set up a campaign to unite public opposition to the expansion of Bankstown airport. Local community action groups, including those which had successfully opposed the Holsworthy airport proposal, and the Bankstown Airport Community and Environment Forum mobilised their forces to go into battle once again.

speech.para: All local, federal and state members of parliament have joined the campaign, with one exception, the member for Hughes. While the community and its elected representatives have rallied to the cause, the member for Hughes has gone into her bunker. As I told the parliament on 8 February, the member for Hughes `seemed deaf' to the true feelings of her constituents if she believed they supported an expansion of Bankstown airport. I also suggested that she should attend the rally planned for the following Sunday if she wanted to hear the true feelings of residents of Moorebank and Chipping Norton. Sadly, the member for Hughes was not at Bankstown Paceway on 11 February to hear more than 3,000 people express their opposition to the expansion of Bankstown airport. But, if the member for Hughes thinks that she can retreat to the leafy suburbs of Menai and Alfords Point, far away from the jet noise at Moorebank and Chipping Norton, she is in for a very big surprise. Maps prepared by consultants to Bankstown council show that jets taking off and landing at Bankstown would also fly over the heart of the Hughes electorate. Perhaps the member for Hughes will hear the views of residents of Alfords Point and Menai a lot louder than she hears those of residents of Moorebank and Chipping Norton in her electorate.

The decision to expand Bankstown airport comes as a result of some of the most muddle-headed thinking ever seen in transport planning. The government faces a dilemma: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport is limited by law to 80 movements per hour and has a night curfew on jet aircraft. Thirty per cent of aircraft using Sydney airport are small regional aircraft, and their movement restricts the operation of larger aircraft. Faced with increasing demand for landing slots at peak times, the government's options are limited to diverting either small regional aircraft or larger, interstate jet aircraft such as Boeing 737s to another airport. With regional centres demanding access to Sydney airport, the minister has taken the second option—that is, to open Bankstown airport to passenger jet aircraft—but this decision has all the markings of policy-making on the run. It is a knee-jerk reaction, taken without considering the impact and certainly taken without consulting the people most affected.

Let us take a closer look at the impact of allowing passenger jets to operate from Bankstown airport. The biggest concern for residents surrounding the airport is the noise levels generated by jet aircraft. To get some idea of the noise impact, I looked at the data provided in the second Sydney airport draft environmental impact statement. Chapter 12 of the statement gives details of the maximum noise levels during landing and take-off for a range of aircraft, including Boeing 737-300 aircraft. The study considered the affected areas which would suffer noise levels of 70 `A' weighted decibels—the level at which normal conversation would be affected. Taking the data for Boeing 737 aircraft, it is clear that noise levels of more than 70 decibels would be felt up to eight kilometres from the runway for aircraft taking off, and up to 10 kilometres away for aircraft landing.

When you look at a map of the areas surrounding Bankstown, it is clear that many residential areas will be subjected to these unacceptable noise levels. To take some examples, areas of Georges Hall, in the electorate of Blaxland, would be less than one kilometre from the runway and could experience noise levels in excess of 90 decibels. That is four times louder than the 70-decibel standard. The same would apply in areas of Condell Park. Areas less than four kilometres from the runway would include areas such as Lansvale and Warwick Farm in my electorate of Fowler and areas of Moorebank and Chipping Norton in the electorate of Hughes. These areas would expect noise levels of up to 80 decibels—that is twice the noise level of 70-decibel areas. Looking at other parts of the Fowler electorate, areas such as Cabramatta and Canley Heights would suffer noise levels well over 70 decibels, and suburbs such as St Johns Park, Edensor Park, Bonnyrigg, Mount Pritchard, Wakeley and Liverpool would experience noise levels above 70 decibels. These are all densely populated suburbs, and I have only looked at areas at the western end of the runway; other areas to the eastern end are equally affected.

The residents of these suburbs have had no warning of the expansion of Bankstown airport. While residents have tolerated a level of noise from light aircraft using Bankstown, the noise levels of jet aircraft are much greater. Bankstown airport has been ruled out as a major airport in every study conducted into Sydney's airport needs since 1946. Bankstown was rejected as a major airport site over 50 years ago. Only this desperate government would select such a site for meeting Sydney's second airport needs. When you take a closer look at Bankstown airport, you can see how bad this plan is. The longest runway at Bankstown is only 1,400 metres—that is less than half the length recommended for aircraft such as Boeing 737s. But there is no land available to extend the runway beyond even 1,800 metres; even that would require buying up properties in the Georges Hall area, and you would still be 1,000 metres—that is, one kilometre—short of the indicative take-off runway length for Boeing 737s.

This was all known back in 1946 when Bankstown was rejected as a major second airport for Sydney. So why does the Minister for Transport and Regional Services think it is a good idea now? Because he needs a quick fix. He wants to be able to tell people in regional New South Wales that they will not be shoved out to Bankstown or Badgerys Creek. This is a decision that smacks of political opportunism and that has nothing to do with good government decision making.

There are many questions that need to be answered in relation to the expansion of Bankstown airport. One question that needs to be answered is the effect of passenger jet aircraft on the capacity of Bankstown airport. Bankstown is the major general aviation airport for Sydney. With over 400,000 movements per year, it is the busiest airport in Australia and is reputed to be the fifth busiest airport in the world. So where will the extra capacity come from? We know that the movement of aircraft such as 737s will reduce the number of light aircraft which can safely use Bankstown. When you realise that almost half of the movements at Bankstown involve flight training, you have to consider the dangerous mixture of passenger jets and L-plated pilots in a very congested airspace. So where will the overflow from Bankstown go? If you take the slip of the tongue that the Prime Minister made in a radio interview, the overflow will go to the Hoxton Park and Canberra airports—no, not Camden airport but Canberra. Hoxton Park airport is restricted to mostly single-engined aircraft. It has no control tower, and it is already close to capacity. Camden airport is in—wait for it—the marginal electorate of Macarthur and is also close to capacity, so it is not even considered for expansion.

That leaves only one site to take up the general aviation overflow from Bankstown. The government already owns an airport site in Western Sydney, of more than 1,700 hectares—that is six times the size of Bankstown—a site for which a $20 million environmental impact statement has already been completed, a site which would have far less noise and other impacts on surrounding residents. The government know this. They know that you cannot put jets into Bankstown without another airport in the Sydney basin to take general aviation. So where will that airport be? Badgerys Creek, of course. That is why they will not sell the site. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I suppose on this occasion, in giving a contribution in the grievance debate, there is really only one question on the national landscape, and that is a sober one for those of us on this side of the House following the results of the state polls in Western Australia and Queensland. There is a question about whether the engagement between this government and the community is one of mutual understanding or whether there has been some kind of a break, a discord, a dissonance in the relationship in which we are not listening to or not hearing or not understanding what the community is saying, and it boils down to the issue of whether this government really deserves to be re-elected. It is to those issues that I wish to address my remarks in the next 10 minutes.

speech.para: There are maybe half a dozen words that continually come up in the discourse as people are trying to understand what it is that people are unhappy about out there in the community and particularly out in the regions. Those words include `globalisation', `competition policy', `deregulation', `foreign investment' and `foreign ownership'. It is fair to say, I think all of us recognise, that there is quite a deep level of apprehension about the implementation of policies in these areas in the general community. A number of those issues can be boiled down to a concern about what people call `national sovereignty'. They express a concern that the Australia which they loved is disappearing and they have a feeling that the key economic assets of the nation are constantly being lost to rapacious foreign interests. I do not wish in any way to mock or deride this anxiety that people feel, which perhaps too often has been the response of the political elites to the genuinely expressed concerns of the community, but I also think that the answer is not today somehow to do a U-turn, to turn around, to abandon the policies because they are too hard or too difficult, if in fact they are right for Australia.

Petrol prices has perhaps been the most frequently articulated emblem of this community apprehension and cited by the Premier of Queensland as the principal reason for his victory, along with the statement that `the bush is burning'. Can I just say that my instinct is that, aside from the actual cost of paying for petrol at the bowser—which is such a democratic experience in this country, wedded as we are to the motor vehicle, with a small population on a vast continent—there is a sense in which the cry of anger on petrol prices is also an expression of frustration at the impotence which Australians can feel and which consumers around the world, I suspect, can feel in purchasing a product or a commodity where they have no control over the price. They see petrol prices rising and falling with rapidity and apparent capricious arbitrariness, and they get angry about that, because it has this implicit message that somehow the individual is powerless, that the individual is a mere pawn and subject to these vast invisible anonymous global forces.

But I just want to affirm in this House the enormous benefits which this country derives and which my constituents in Parramatta derive from Australia's engagement with the rest of the world. For just as there are commodities in which Australia consumers are price-takers, there is also an opportunity in the global market for Australians to be employed in a competitive race to deliver goods and services to people in other countries all over the world. We have to keep asking ourselves, `Do we want to engineer the Australian economy purely to meet the needs of the 19 million-odd Australian citizens who reside here or do we have the guts and the vision to really have a crack at penetrating the world market, the six billion people who reside in the other 180-odd countries, protectorates and dominions recognised by the United Nations?' In a country which, for example, in the agricultural sector produces four times as much product as the Australian people can consume, the answer is a starkly simple one: that we have no choice but to constantly seek to gain access to the markets of other countries around the world if we are going to be able to unload the 75 per cent of our agricultural product which cannot be consumed in this country.

I want to say to the people in my electorate of Parramatta there is—there and more widely—a concern about what people say is the erosion of national sovereignty that comes from Australia's engagement with multilateral organisations, among them the World Trade Organisation. They feel that the dice is weighted against us, that there is somehow an unfair engagement and that these bureaucrats down here in Canberra, and we politicians acting as their puppets, if you like, are constantly signing away Australia's interests to allow foreign products and foreign services to be flooded into the Australian market. I just want to root this argument in a few key facts. The first of those is that in the past year exports grew 25 per cent Australia-wide, taking them to $142 billion or 24 per cent of our gross domestic product. That means that one dollar in every four in our economy is being generated by providing goods and services to people who do not live in Australia. One job in every four is being generated by Australians engaged in export. If we seek to deny others fair access to Australian markets, we also have to be prepared to turn around to those one in four and explain to them what we are going to do for them when foreign markets around the world say to Australians, `You cannot have access to our market.'

In the United Kingdom, for example, this year, for the first time, Australian wine will be the most consumed of any foreign wine in Great Britain. The reason for that is that we have a fantastically productive group of vignerons in this country. They are doing a tremendous job of producing a great product and of marketing it effectively. If we are going to turn around and say to the English that they cannot have access to our markets, all of those jobs—all of that activity—are in jeopardy.

There are 14 local government areas in Greater Western Sydney. Those 14 local government areas generate over $3.5 billion a year in exports. Of those 14 local government areas, Parramatta has the highest proportion of export oriented businesses. In fact, fully 250 businesses in Parramatta are engaged primarily in export. Those 250 businesses are all employing one, two, three, five, 20 people. Rod Hunwick, at Northmead, has just produced the Hunwick Harrop motor cycle, Australia's first domestically produced motor cycle for many, many years. He is looking to penetrate the United States market with a spectacular motorbike that is competing with Harley Davidson and taking the place by storm. Am I going to turn around to Rod and say, `Well, because we don't want foreign investment in this country, you are going to be denied the opportunity to take a crack at the American market?' What am I going to say to those 250 other businesses who are employing Australians, making a contribution to the gross domestic product, because Australia is engaged in this open economy?

We can cite example after example of other countries being forced to give greater access to Australia for our products. In competition policy, another bugbear, I note that the introduction of Aussie Home Loans—based in Parramatta—to the mortgage originator market saw a 1.5 per cent reduction in the rate of home loans being charged to the average Australian, which meant savings of $250 a month to Australian families. That is competition policy. It may be unpopular in some parts of Australia, but we have to remember Australians are consumers as well as producers; every time we put capital into a sector which is non-competitive over the long run, we deny capital to these newly emerging businesses, to those having a crack at new markets who are really building Australia. I want to ask the Australian people to think through these issues and not simply react to words and slogans. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise today to highlight what I consider is extraordinary behaviour within the car insurance industry by some of its major players. When I say `extraordinary behaviour', I mean standover tactics, bullying and the ripping off of motorists and the accident repair industry. This extortion must be investigated by the ACCC. To date, they appear reluctant to do so. Many motorists are suffering because of their inaction, and many small businesses are hitting the fence because of the practices of large insurers in the car repair industry, especially the Royal Automobile Club of Victoria. I want to detail some of the examples of some of these dodgy practices later, but I will first provide a framework of the industry.

speech.para: The car repair industry itself has 1,500 accident repair centres in Victoria. Seventy per cent of the moneys for the repair of cars comes from insurance companies. Accident repair centres have received no increase in payments from the insurance companies for the last three years, even thought the costs of parts and other things have increased by some 23 per cent. With the introduction of the GST there was no increase in payments to accident repairers as well. Deloittes estimated that a $400 million to $500 million windfall came to insurance companies through not allowing an increase for these accident repair centres. Insurance companies told the ACCC that they would pass this on to consumers. I believe the consumers are still waiting for this. There have been long-running battles between car manufacturers and insurance companies over the costs of spare parts. Car manufacturers have a mark-up of between 100 per cent and 1,000 per cent on spare parts for cars. The ACCC in its former guise looked into this in the eighties. Insurance companies appeared to be cutting on quality and on paying accident repair centres to address this cost problem.

There is, however, in the midst of this, a David of the industry who has brought these matters to light. He is Gerry Raleigh, who is the owner of Kerry Panels. He has an excellent reputation in the industry, being an approved repairer for Ferrari, Eunos, Toyota and Audi. Gerry lost over $90,000 in turnover last year because he fought the RACV over their policies. He has beaten the RACV many times in court when rectifying cars previously repaired in their accident repair centres or RACV approved repairers. He is a small man fighting a Goliath in the industry.

As a result of his victories when seeking proper repairs for clients of the RACV, they have reacted by bullying him, removing business from his shop and then having the audacity to check over 14 repairs he had previously done for them to try to find faults. They found nothing. David Herford of the RACV has continuously slandered him on 3LO and 3AW but never produced evidence. Mr Herford knows that Mr Raleigh and Kerry Panels cannot afford to sue him for defamation.

Let me give some indication of the support or lack of support for these claims. The ACCC has been approached numerous times by the VACC; the state minister for small business, Marsha Thomson; Tony Robinson; the AWU Secretary, Bill Shorten; and Don Nardella. To date, it appears too difficult for the ACCC to look into. They want nice easy examples from persons reliant upon insurance companies for their livelihood. Both Peter Reith and Louise Asher thought it was important that small business was protected from unfair practices, but they have done nothing about this. The report by Jack Hammond QC into the practices of the RACV and like companies on behalf of the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce stated that in his opinion the RACV had breached the Trade Practices Act by using contracts that limited competition, misusing market power, exclusive dealing and unconscionable conduct. The ACCC, in its response to Jack Hammond, in February this year said:

quote.para: While, on balance, RACV's actions may be considered inflexible, unfair or unreasonable, they are unlikely to be viewed as being so against conscience as to warrant a court's intervention.

speech.para: They are telling us that something is not quite right but that they do not wish to push it further. It appears to me that the only way we will catch crooks in the car insurance industry is to have a private inquiry undertaken by the ACCC where the insurance companies simply are not able to find out who put in submissions. In this way, we could stop retribution against good people like Gerry Raleigh. Only in this way will the ACCC fully understand the practices of these insurance companies.

In the time I have available, I would like to give some instances of abuse which I think prove that the RACV and others are simply not playing according to the rules. I am actually going to use the words of Mr David Herford, General Manager of RACV Insurance, and others, such as the Insurance Council of Australia, to compare the way in which things are meant to be done to how they actually are done.

I will give you the example of a large eastern based city council in Victoria. A council car ran into a third party insured by the RACV. Through the diligent work of the safety and insurance coordinator and Mr Gerry Raleigh, they inspected the car and found out that the RACV was charging for work never done. Further, they asked for photos of the accident, but the RACV told them that, unlike other insurers in the industry, they did not take photos. Finally, after doing due diligence on the RACV, the council decided to pay a lower amount to them. The RACV never complained. I wonder why! Were they trying to rip off local government or were they just incompetent? Listen to the words of Mr Herford having a go at Gerry Raleigh:

quote.para: Now along the way we often come to grips with ... repairers who perhaps try to take money where they shouldn't be taking money.

speech.para: Like the RACV.There is also this fine document, utilised by the RACV, that came across my desk called a `Potential fraud indicator'. Let me comment on this document. It is racist, discriminatory and downright dangerous. This is a sign of a company out of control. On this fraud indicator the signs of a potential fraudster include the ethnicity of the insured, whether or not the vehicle was stolen from the western suburbs, whether the nationality of the parties is similar, whether or not the person is unemployed and whether or not the claimant is aged between 21 and 25 years of age.

To illustrate the malignant nature of this process, I came across a case in my office of a Mrs K. Mrs K. was 21 years of age and was driving her mother's car. She happens to be Turkish. She crashed her mother's car and then rang the RACV to get it towed to a repair centre. The RACV told her that they would not do this. When she went back to get the car with her father, it was stolen. So what was the RACV's reaction? Stonewall the family, interrogate the young lady and tell the family: `We know you stole it.' After six months of these threats they finally settled.

So you may pay the premium and be honest in your dealings, but getting money from the RACV is like getting blood out of a stone, especially if you are Turkish and young. Obviously, only people of English origins should be trusted—particularly according to this document.

I will give you the case of a Bill Gommers. Mr Gommers crashed his car and then tried to take it to his panel beater, Mr Gerry Raleigh. All he got was the run-around by the RACV. No such thing as choice if you want to go to Mr Raleigh! Mr Gommers got three quotes and Mr Raleigh was the cheapest. When the assessor from the RACV came to look at the car, Mr Gommers was told that he could have his own panel beater but that he would have to pay for the repairs himself and they would pay after 30 days. Not only did they do this but they also accused Mr Gommers of being a mouthpiece for Mr Gerry Raleigh. Finally, Mr Gommers rang the complaints unit of the insurance industry. The RACV changed its mind and paid out in five days. He was never aware that to have choice with the RACV, you have to go to their repairers. You would not know it, however, if you listened to what Mr Herford said on 3LO in April 1999:

quote.para: Well, you know, we do, as being fair, allow customers to have complete freedom of choice in the sense of where the car is fixed. It is enshrined in the policy document that we actually sell.

speech.para: Let me give you another example of a Mrs Duncan of Box Hill South. Mrs Duncan had an accident and the car was taken to the RACV's repair centre in Rooks Road, Nunawading. After one month, the car was collected and Mrs Duncan had Mr Raleigh check the car. The list of faults was long and included a bent chassis. She took the car back for further repairs. All that the people at the RACV told her was that she was wrong about the further repairs required. It took her six trips back to the RACV repair centre to have everything rectified. This is what the Sun Herald said in May 1999:

quote.para: Mr Herford said that the RACV was the leading car insurer in the state and he defended the RACV's two crash repair centres at Cheltenham North in Vermont as the finest in the business.

speech.para: I wonder if Mrs Duncan would agree. I do not think so, after reading her letter to the RACV, which said, amongst other things:

quote.para: There is a slogan on your wall in the reception area `Just like sending your car to a private hospital.' Does it not matter that people may end up in hospital due to endless follow-up procedures caused by RACV's poor work practices regarding the repair of their vehicles?

speech.para: I could give you many other examples but, unfortunately, time does not permit me to detail them. But what we have heard tonight is an example of vulnerable motorists being ripped off with shoddy work practices, panel beaters being driven to the wall unless they comply with the insurance industry and a weak ACCC not willing to conduct a proper investigation. The RACV puts itself forward as a defender of motorists' rights. On what we have heard tonight, we know that this is simply not believable. These insurance companies, including the RACV, should take up their concerns over repair costs with the car manufacturers instead of beating panel beaters into submission and dropping the quality of repairs for their customers, supposedly their most important asset. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Thank you for the opportunity to raise some matters of genuine interest to my electorate of Barker and the general community in relation to the political landscape. The recent state elections in Western Australia and Queensland have given all members of federal parliament a chance to ponder on what the people of Australia want and demand from their representatives, and in both of these elections there were many such demands.

speech.para: Leadership, stability and consistency were, I believe, the paramount reasons for the re-election of a Labor government in Queensland with such a huge majority. It did not seem to matter that the Labor frontbench in Queensland seemed to consist of one man with a broad grin wherever he went and no-one else was to be seen. It did not seem to matter that the Labor government had presided over the worst unemployment record of any mainland state, when `Jobs, jobs, jobs' was Beattie's catchcry to get elected in the first place. And it did not seem to matter that Queensland Labor was endemically affected by electoral rorts within its own ranks. All that mattered to the Queensland voters was that the coalition was seen as divided over preference deals with One Nation and that its leadership was seen as unstable, unfit to govern and unlikely to perform.

Similar things happened in Western Australia, although not to the same extent. There was a feeling that the Court government was not travelling perfectly, that elements within were not totally supportive of Premier Court and that there had been too many backflips, especially on such things as regional forest agreements, where, in actual fact, nobody ended up winning except the Labor Party and the loony left element of the environmental lobby. So there are lessons to be learned for all of us, but the biggest lesson is to treat One Nation for what it is and not flirt with their crackpot ideas, which I will address shortly.

It is interesting to note that the three seats that One Nation appear to have won in Queensland were won with National Party preferences, but that One Nation did not deliver any seats to the coalition, which must serve as a timely reminder to anyone of a mind to flirt with this extremist party. Unfortunately, there are many good people out there who have voted for One Nation, for lots of different reasons which range from the notion that the major political parties are not listening—often reinforced by populist night time talkback radio, whose main aim is to keep people awake and listening—to other reasons, including the idea of sending a message to the major political parties, or of making a protest vote on some issue dear to their hearts, simply because a voter is not sure who to vote for so they vote for someone who has not got a chance of winning government. It is ironic that many of these good voters who want stability end up voting against stability by a vote for other than a majority party.

Do not get me wrong, it is everyone's right to vote for whomever they want and for whatever reason they want, just as it is my duty to represent all those people who do not vote for me for whatever reason. I am sure that everyone in this House will attest to the fact that they spend more time listening than anything else. But, of course, there are many different views out there and if we support some views we rarely get the accolade of listening but if the group with the opposite view does not get its way, then, ipso facto, that means we are not listening. Such is the lot of an MP, but I am sure all sides of the political spectrum in the House realise this and know that we just have to get on with the job of trying to do the best we can.

It is worth returning to the subject of Pauline Hanson and One Nation and the effect it is having on Australia and the way we, as politicians, need to deal with it. The major political parties have, under their leadership, strongly urged placing One Nation last, and Hanson hates this because it does not give her the credibility she craves. But more of this later, when I intend to point out her obvious failings. At least Rob Borbidge had the leadership integrity to call for putting One Nation last, which strongly contrasted with that of Premier Beattie, who, to my knowledge, never had the gumption to do so and, of course, escaped any great scrutiny from the media on this lack of integrity and this short-term political expediency. At least Bob Carr, another Labor leader, was not prepared to follow this tacky strategy. The more people who expose Hansonism for what it is, the less people will be inclined to support her dangerous ideas.

It is a disappointment to see the way that the federal Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, treats her misguided mantra on the so-called evils of globalisation. His pathetic attitude was to say that we should just try to treat the effects of globalisation more kindly, whereas a real leader would debunk her ideas as dangerous, and argue all the benefits that come from the access to world markets for our farmers and exporters. Do we ever hear this from Beazley? Of course not, because he wants to surf in on the disaffected voters who support Hansonism, without really attacking her cuckoo land ideas. It is a shame that that course of action has been taken. Frankly, I do not think he will ever be the leader of this country because he is not showing any signs of being a leader so far.

We should be caring, of course, about those who suffer from the effects of the deregulation and globalisation, but also point out the folly of supporting outdated and dangerous answers such as the banning of imports and tariff taxes on our consumer goods. To stop globalisation we would have to go back to the horse and cart, as a former member of this House, Bert Kelly, would say, and this country owes a lot to the sometimes laconic but always modest former member for Wakefield. Of course, the world is getting smaller and, without banning the use of computers and the Internet, it will continue to get smaller. But globalisation has many benefits, and when our farmers are so efficient that we produce five times what we can consume on our home market, it stands to reason that we need to export 80 per cent of what we produce. Hanson's silly answer is to ban imports, but what do we do with the other 80 per cent of what our farmers produce? Of course, she has never had an answer to that.

Do we really think that other countries will stand idly by while we ban their exports and hope they will not ban ours? Of course not. The answer is to encourage world trade and open access to our products, which also means a reciprocal opening up of our markets, provided there is no threat to our clean green image, of our food especially. We need only to look at those agricultural products that have benefited from globalisation and greater access. The wine industry, which is a very important industry to the electorate of Barker, is booming thanks to greater access to world markets, especially Europe. This came about through World Trade Organisation negotiations, yet Pauline Hanson and her League of Rights cousins continually attack the WTO as something evil.

The lamb industry continues to do well because of greater access to world markets, and it was the World Trade Organisation that ensured that the shoddy action taken by the US market to restrict our lamb was seen for what it was. But apparently for Hanson and the League of Righters, it is evil and hurts our farmers. In fact, the opposite happens. The beef industry is doing extraordinarily well due to the greater access gained to world markets by, firstly, Tim Fischer and, since then, Mark Vaile, as coalition trade ministers. There is no doubt that our freedom from exotic diseases, such as mad cow disease, scrapie and foot and mouth, gives confidence to our consumers and overseas importers. We might all remember that, at the last election, the pork industry, strongly supported by Hanson and the League of Rights, suggested that the answer to falling prices was to ban the import of pork. No matter that this would lead to reciprocal bans on other Australian farm products worth eight times as much. Of course, it was a stupid, short-sighted non-answer, and the action we took to encourage the exports of pork has proven to be most beneficial—to the point where the pork industry is now thriving.

Do we hear these sorts of arguments from the Leader of the Opposition? No, we do not because he does not have the ticker to take it up to Pauline Hanson. He does not understand farmers and no amount of phoney bus tours will ever convince them otherwise. Rural leadership was shown by Senator Ron Boswell who has taken Hanson head-on by showing how loony One Nation and the League of Rights were by promoting the Port Arthur massacre as some sort of United Nations conspiracy to take our guns away. If Hanson had her way she would be putting semi-automatic guns back into the community. Even the Sporting Shooters Association of Australia has rejected this loony tune. We must reject Hanson and her League of Rights cousins and do it forcefully. She has no credibility and we must not give her any if we want our system to survive with stability and credibility. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to outline the circumstances that have led to me being given a clean bill of health by the Federal Police in relation to untrue allegations contained in a fabricated re-enactment broadcast on 27 November 2000 on the ABC regarding the 1996 federal election. I would like to commend the police officers I dealt with in the Australian Federal Police for their professional conduct in this investigation. This was a not a matter that in the first instance should have been referred to the Australian Federal Police because there were on the public record categorical denials from national Labor and Democrat spokesmen disproving these false allegations and thereby removing any hint of illegality. However, given the media attention focusing on the 7.30 Report's fabricated re-enactment, I believe the Australian Federal Police investigation was the only way I could have ever cleared my name from the untrue smear contained in the program.

speech.para: The replay of this re-enactment on news broadcasts, the references to and repetition of the image of brown paper envelopes, the government's referral to the Australian Electoral Commission and ultimately to the Australian Federal Police, all called into question my standing in the community. The repetition by senior government ministers of these untrue allegations and stunts like that performed by the member for Sturt have all been aimed at sullying my name. These false allegations were part of a vendetta by a bitter individual and were conveniently packaged in a fabricated re-enactment by an unprofessional journalist that was broadcast across Australia.

Today I want to set the record straight. The re-enactment was of an event that never happened. I do not want to spend much time on the false allegations themselves, but I do want to say this: the campaign contribution made to the Democrats was not an illegal secret inducement. The $500 campaign contribution was given, and used, to buy election signs and was completely unrelated to preferences. It was not in a brown paper bag or brown envelope, and, most importantly, had nothing to do with the preference decision that was taken at a national level, by national negotiators who all rejected the allegation prior to the 7.30 Report screening the re-enactment.

The re-enactment on the ABC was in breach of the ABC's own editorial policies, the ABC Code of Practice and the journalists' code of ethics. It was irresponsible sensationalism adopting the McCarthyist attitude `know nothing, suspect everything'. Unsupported and denied allegations should never be put to air, but when they are done in such a way as to create a dramatic image, they leave a lasting impression, long after the real facts have come out. Of critical relevance has been the unethical and unprofessional conduct of the journalist who reported this story.

Mr Wayne Sanderson ignored all of the evidence put to him by Mr Ian Roland, the Democrat campaign director, and my own categorical denials, and he proceeded with a story that had been completely denied by the two central people critical to the allegation. Mr Sanderson also ignored the denial of Senator Andrew Bartlett, who told him there had been no local Democrat influence in the national preference decision, and the denial of Senator Robert Ray, the national ALP negotiator. Instead, Mr Sanderson relied upon the evidence of Mr Lee Bermingham, a person with a longstanding personal grudge against me since his sacking from the Labor Party in 1997. Mr Roland has also been grievously slandered by this program. Since the program went to air, he has said to me and others:

quote.para: Despite me refuting the scurrilous allegations made by Mr Bermingham on at least 6 occasions during our meeting—

speech.para: which was prior to the program going to air—

quote.para: he—

speech.para: that is, Sanderson—

quote.para: still seemed obsessed by pursing the Bermingham lies as matter of fact. I warned Sanderson he was walking on dangerous ground.

speech.para: And Senator Bartlett has had a similar experience. Senator Bartlett, who was also misrepresented on the 7.30 Report, directly denied to Mr Sanderson, before the story went to air, key elements of the story which eventually went to air. Mr Sanderson told the Senator he was `going to get Swan', prior to the program going to air. The only person the 7.30 Report relied upon for its factual content, Mr Bermingham, now appears to be walking away from the original story by the comments he made in the Courier Mail on 21 February this year, when he said:

quote.para: I have never disputed there may have been an innocent explanation for what took place.

speech.para: Further to this, Mr Sanderson never at any stage prior to putting the program to air, when talking to me or my legal adviser, outlined the details of the re-enactment so I could respond. Mr Speaker, Mr Sanderson and the 7.30 Report are in breach of the ABC editorial policy section 4.3, `Accuracy, impartiality and objectivity', as well as section 4.8, relating to re-enactments. They are also in breach of the ABC Code of Practice sections 4.1(a), 4.1(c), 4.2(a) and 4.2(b). Mr Sanderson has, repeatedly, on ABC radio, denigrated, ridiculed and misrepresented events regarding me. He has a hatred and an obsession with any person seen to have been close to or involved in the Goss government.

On one occasion prior to the 7.30 Report re-enactment, Mr Sanderson claimed on ABC radio that I was a political buffoon because in 1995 I was responsible in some way for the `koala road' which he said led to the downfall of the Goss government. In 1995, I was the member for Lilley and spent 18 months opposing the then transport minister, David Hamill, and his attempts to build new roads, including one right through my electorate. On another occasion, Mr Sanderson put to air an accusation I was a sympathiser with the One Nation Party—an accusation I entirely reject—without even bothering to seek a response from me.

This type of misrepresentation has at times occurred on a daily basis on Brisbane ABC radio and never has Mr Sanderson bothered to call me to check the accuracy of such assertions. Since my clearance on Friday, 16 February, I have not been contacted by the Andrew Carroll morning show in Queensland or by any other ABC radio current affairs program in Queensland to address the imbalance created by the continuous airplay of these malicious allegations prior to Christmas. Mr Sanderson is part of a small clique of people pursuing political vendettas against me, and his journalistic conduct has been both unethical and unprofessional. It was this prejudice that led Mr Sanderson to fabricate the image of a secret transfer of money in a brown envelope. He knew this would translate in the wider media into images of the brown paper bags of the Bjelke-Petersen era.

It is a matter of common knowledge in and around the ABC and throughout Brisbane's political circles that Mr Sanderson and his boss Mr Steve Austin regularly joke about getting Swan and other prominent Labor identities in Queensland. This is in breach of all of the editorial policies and codes of ethics previously mentioned. But Mr Sanderson in particular is in breach of section 2.4 of the Code of Practice relating to discrimination by the presentation or portrayal of people in a way which is likely to encourage denigration because of their political belief.

I believe the ABC must immediately investigate all of these matters under sections 8.1 and 8.2 of their Code of Practice. There is a very important point of natural justice and fair play here. I say to all those in the gallery here and other journalists who give Mr Sanderson credence and who have been swept up in the hysteria: just remember the immortal lines from Emile Zola, defending Dreyfus:

quote.para: But it is with this poisoned bread that the unclean press has been nourishing our poor people now for months. And it is not surprising if we are witnessing a dangerous crisis, for when folly and lies are thus sown broadcast, you necessarily reap insanity.

speech.para: I ask all working journalists to think seriously about the issues involved in this re-enactment. Think about it like this. What if you were accused by somebody you had worked with as a journalist and this person no longer worked with you because they had been sacked from your bureau? What if this former colleague was now alleging they had seen you being improperly influenced by a source to write or put to air a particular story? What if a 7.30 Report journalist who had a longstanding grudge against you convinced his superiors to put to air a re-enactment of the event starring your former colleague? What if the 7.30 Report reporter failed to ask you about any of the details of the proposed re-enactment, ignored your denials, ignored the denials of your most senior colleagues and broadcast the story? What if that re-enactment was rebroadcast across all of the commercial channels in the country, with your friends, family and supporters viewing the image of an event that never happened? What if you were stood down for 80 days? What if your friends and family were harassed and ridiculed? What steps would be available to you to secure some justice?

Let me say that this episode has been hard on me and my family, and I thank them for their support and their love during this period. It has also been hard on Mr Roland and has severely affected his health. I feel very sorry for him for being dragged into this public humiliation because of a journalist's personal hatred of me.

In closing, let me say this: for me, the first step towards justice is today to ask the ABC to do the right thing: to have a proper investigation. This man has politically stalked me, my friends and my family because of his political obsession. He has done this as a public employee in the ABC and he has done this despite clear evidence that his story was wrong. But then Mr Sanderson did not want to hear the truth. He certainly did not want to broadcast the truth. I have the highest regard for the ABC—I am one of its strongest supporters in this parliament—but, if it is to retain its respect and standing, it must immediately investigate the activities of one or two individuals and do something about the injustices that I have outlined here this evening.

talk.start.para: —I want to refer to an article that appeared in the Queensland Country Life of 25 January 2001. This article was entitled `Why single desks are failures' and it was written by Mr Graeme Samuel, the president of the National Competition Council. This article has caused great disquiet amongst cane farmers throughout Queensland. I would like to quote from the article, if I may. It started:

quote.para: If it wasn't so incredibly serious, government intervention in agricultural marketing in the year 2001 would be very, very funny—a cross between the keystone cops and big-brother style government.

speech.para: Later on in the article Mr Samuel goes on to say:

quote.para: Deregulation is all about choice for the grower and competition is all about performance by the marketer. For example, if Queensland's sugarcane growers were unhappy with the management decisions of the Queensland Sugar Corporation (which last year meant that growers received no benefit from the doubling of world sugar prices between March and August), they would be free to investigate other marketing options.

speech.para: I would like to take up the point that Mr Samuel made about Queensland Sugar Corporation, now Queensland Sugar Ltd, and his assertion that growers received no benefit from the doubling of world prices between March and August. The fact of the matter is that, if Mr Samuel had stirred himself from his ivory tower in Melbourne and knew a little bit about the production of sugarcane in Queensland, he might in fact have had the facts to hand. The reality is that Queensland Sugar Ltd had to satisfy long-term contracts. All those in rural Australia know that most products are sold under long-term contracts. Queensland Sugar Ltd, understanding that our sugar industry has a reputation as the most consistent supplier of raw sugar in the world, quite rightly places great importance on keeping faith with its long-term contracts. The difficulty is that, instead of five million tonnes of raw sugar being produced in Queensland, there was only 3.86 million. Once it had fulfilled its long-term contracts, there was simply no surplus left to be able to take advantage of the rising price. Ian White, the chief executive officer of Queensland Sugar Ltd, has always said that QSL is not a speculator. QSL tries very hard to maintain its excellent reputation for quality production and consistency. So Mr Samuel next time might check a few facts before he goes into print.

There has been disquiet caused by Mr Samuel's denigration of Queensland Sugar Ltd, which, as I said, have done a magnificent job over the years maximising returns to millers and growers. The disquiet is caused by the suggestion that there should be another review of the Queensland sugar industry single-desk arrangements just four years after the last review was completed. That last review in 1996 cost the industry some $2 million in consultancy. There were 46 recommendations emanating from the review, including one that there should be no further review for at least a decade. I might say that the farmers very reluctantly gave up their tariff at that time, which amounted to some $1,500 per farm on average—an amount that, with the industry now on its knees, would have been very welcome.

Nonetheless, the farmers kept faith with the recommendations, and so did the government, in full. I believe that they now look to the federal government to ensure that Mr Samuel's hasty recommendation that a mere four years after the completion of that review the single desk should again be up for grabs must be rejected. We have had an assurance, in fact a guarantee, from the Deputy Prime Minister that their expectations will be met, as will the expectations of wheat farmers, that the single-desk powers of Queensland Sugar Ltd and the Australian Wheat Board will be retained. I think it is a matter of great regret that a few short weeks before the Queensland election Mr Samuel chose to try to undermine not only the coalition opposition in Queensland but also the federal coalition government by frightening farmers. The sugar industry in Queensland are rightly very appreciative of the sugar assistance package and the assurances they have been given. They have kept their side of the bargain that was made following the sugar industry review.

I do not think it is appropriate for bureaucrats such as Mr Samuels to decide that they can enter political debate and override commitments made by governments. If Mr Samuels wants to do that, he should nominate for a federal seat. He would be very welcome to do that in North Queensland. There are any number of federal seats for which he could nominate. In doing that, he could explain to the growers there why he believes the statutory marketing arrangements are very funny. I think he would get a very warm reception in North Queensland. I just hope he keeps his motor running when he does!

The government will not be swayed by a one-year performance of Queensland Sugar Corporation—taking into account that they have kept the reputation for consistent supply—which of course was due to a massive decline in sugar production caused by poor weather and crop disease. The predictions for the sugar price for the current crop are such that growers can expect a considerably higher return this year. We are looking at prices of around 10.24c per litre, a considerable improvement on 4.86c two years ago.

I would like to move on to the Productivity Commission report into the impact of competition policy reforms on rural and regional Australia. This makes very interesting reading. In fact, I got my copy out again to refresh my memory. I remind the President of the National Competition Council of some of the recommendations that the Productivity Commission made and of some of their findings. The key messages were as follows. The early effects of national competition policy have favoured metropolitan areas more than rural and regional areas and there is likely to be more variation in the incidence of benefits and costs of NCP among country regions than in metropolitan areas. They concluded that the dismantling of statutory marketing arrangements would disadvantage producers. In fact, they said there would be a channelling of resources and income from producers to consumers, predominantly in metropolitan areas.

I pick up on a point made by the member for Parramatta: for Australian producers, exports are absolutely vital. For once I agree with the member for Parramatta. He is absolutely right. A small country with a large surplus in agricultural production has to export. May I assure the member for Parramatta that 92 per cent of Australia's sugar is exported. We really do know how to compete on a corrupted world market where every other sugar producer is subsidised. If that is not competition, I do not know what is. I am glad to accept the advice of the member for Parramatta. I assure him that the sugar industry is taking it to heart and exporting.

I would like to continue with the Productivity Commission report. They went on to say about primary producers and the dismantling of statutory marketing arrangements that the impact on producers may be large and regionally concentrated and could pose adjustment difficulties for affected communities. One of the arguments constantly put by Mr Samuels is that there should be assistance. He is correct in saying that, under national competition policy guidelines, they call for assistance to affected producers. Farmers do not want to become a charity case. They do not want to be given a handout. They want to be able to do what they do well, which is to produce. They do not want to be adjusted out of the industry—read for that `removed'. They would simply like to be able to keep their marketing arrangements, compete in a highly corrupted world market and sell their produce for Australia.

The National Competition Council has been instructed by the Productivity Commission that they should no longer be asked to conduct legislation reviews. Presumably, this would include legislation which involves statutory marketing authorities. The results of national competition policy are not as glowing as they would appear. Residential users of electricity are paying three per cent less for electricity, while commercial and industrial users are paying 22 per cent less. In Mr Samuels's home state of Victoria, gas prices for residential customers have risen by seven per cent while prices for industrial users have fallen by 22 per cent. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: (Mr Mossfield)—The Speaker has received a message from the Senate acquainting the House that Senator Abetz has been discharged from the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund and that Senator Mason has been appointed a member of the committee.

debateinfo.title: NATIONAL MUSEUM OF AUSTRALIA AMENDMENT BILL 2001

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.28 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 8 February, on motion by Mr Hockey:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr Kelvin Thomson moved by way of amendment:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its treatment of Medicare and effective Americanisation of the health system and its taxation indexation policies and their effect on the community and calls on the Government to get behind Labor's plans to rebuild Medicare”.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak tonight on the Medicare Levy Amendment (CPI Indexation) Bill (No. 2) 2000. I have spoken on a number of occasions about the crisis in our public hospitals. These problems are a consequence of the underfunding by both state and federal Liberal governments that has resulted in the closure of wards for safety reasons because there are simply not enough staff. After seven years of a Liberal state government in which the public hospital system has been afforded the lowest priority, Premier Olsen has announced that he will cancel next year's Le Mans car race in Adelaide because the choice, according to him, is a car race or 200 nurses. It seems that Mr Olsen has been looking at the reports from his pollsters. He has at last noticed what he would have known years ago if he had been listening to the South Australian public and their concerns about the indulgence of his government. There have been a lot of car races, as well as the financial debacle of the Hindmarsh soccer stadium, since former Premier Dean Brown first cut $140 million in a single year from the state's hospital system. Since then, the Howard government has refused to adequately fund South Australia's public hospital system. What most people want is for their government to put the priority on maintaining basic services such as public hospitals and schools. The question is: will the money saved from the cancellation of the Le Mans car race translate into any improvement in our public hospitals? We will have to wait and see whether he means an additional 200 nurses or not having to cut 200 more.

speech.para: The poor state of South Australia's public hospitals relative to the rest of the country is spelt out in the Productivity Commission's Report on Government Services 2001, released this month. The report singles out South Australia as among the worst performing states on health care. The report covers emergency department waiting times across five triage categories from resuscitation to non-urgent. Patients in category 1 are in cardiac arrest or need resuscitation. Patients in category 2 are emergency cases and need to be seen within 10 minutes. In this category, we are talking about patients suffering chest pains and possible heart attacks, strokes, trauma to the head and severe shortness of breath—that is, patients whose condition could rapidly deteriorate while they wait. The report shows that, in 1998-99, 28 per cent of emergency patients waited longer than 10 minutes. Patients in category 3 are urgent cases and need to be seen within 30 minutes. Typically, urgent cases include abdominal pain, trauma or renal and biliary conditions. The report shows that 37 per cent of patients with these conditions waited longer than the prescribed 30 minutes. Patients in category 4 are semi-urgent cases. The prescribed waiting time of 60 minutes for these patients was exceeded in 35 per cent of cases. These figures confirm the pressures on our emergency departments, and every other bit of evidence suggests that these pressures have worsened since 1998-99.

Our medical staff are working harder than ever to limit the wait of sick South Australians and are having to do more with the inadequate resources provided by the Olsen and Howard governments. I was alarmed by the Productivity Commission's findings that South Australia has the highest rate of hospital acquired infections anywhere in Australia. More than three per cent of patients were infected following surgery, as a result of their hospital visit, while the Australian average was about two per cent. The rate for post-operative infection following contaminated surgery—that is, surgery that breaches the gastro-intestinal, respiratory or urinary tract—was higher than other states at 4.6 per cent. South Australia is also the leader in unexpected readmissions to hospitals. More South Australians return to hospital within 28 days of their initial discharge than do patients in any other state. That means patients are often being discharged sooner than is clinically desirable, to free up beds.

The Productivity Commission scores the health performance of Australia's states and territories across a range of indicators. Its report is damning evidence that the Olsen and Howard governments are guilty of neglect of South Australia's health care. It is no wonder that South Australia is the only state not to undertake patient surveys and feedback. Every other state conducted patient satisfaction surveys in the year 2000. In fact, patient feedback has not been sought in South Australia in any of the years included in the report. The South Australian government advised the Productivity Commission that it will undertake a telephone survey of patients in March of this year. I wonder whether it is going to release the results of that! There can be no argument that South Australia's public hospitals are suffering deliberate neglect from the Olsen and Howard governments. The statistics are clear and the victims are numerous. Every week I am meeting South Australians who deserve care but are not getting the care they need.

I want to briefly share the experiences of three constituents whose cases are typical of many. Mrs Margaret Knox of Port Noarlunga South needs her knee replaced. She has needed it replaced since October 1998 but has had to endure worsening pain and diminishing mobility for over two years. Her operation was scheduled for 12 January this year, but an infection caused its cancellation. After a further six weeks wait, Mrs Knox's re-scheduled operation was for 23 February, but it was again cancelled—this time due to industrial action by the hospital's nurses. Mrs Knox was advised of the cancellation at 7 o'clock on the night before her admission. The hospital tried to do the surgery as soon as possible because Mrs Knox's case was now considered semi-urgent, but the demand for accident and emergency beds and the nurses' industrial action to ensure minimum staffing levels forced its cancellation. Mrs Knox is due for admission again on 13 March. Meanwhile, her daily dosage of morphine has been increased from four five-milligram tablets to eight tablets a day. She was taking the dose of four tablets a day late last year, when she first came to see me. Mrs Knox wants it known that she supports the nurses' industrial action. Mrs Knox's experience at FMC is a classic reflection of the blow-out in waiting lists for elective surgery. As our hospitals attempt to meet increasing patient demand without commensurate increases in funding, new fees and charges are being levied.

Another constituent has brought to my attention the decision by FMC to supply only one breast prosthesis to mastectomy patients. Breast prostheses need replacing once a year and cost $150. Previously the supply of breast prostheses at FMC was free. This is one of the hard decisions the hospital has had to make in cutting its budget to provide essential health services.

The third case is from a teenager, Rachel Vandersluys, who sent me an email yesterday. She has a major cyst in the joint of her wrist that has stopped her participation in her chosen sports for a season and threatens her matriculation studies because, unless it is treated, she will have great difficulty writing long essays. She wrote:

quote.para: I cannot train. I have lost my spot in my sports. I know I will have to work extra hard to regain my fitness. I am trying to do my matriculation with a ganglion on my writing hand. I have been under care at Flinders Medical Centre since November. It took a month before I could see a specialist in the plastics unit. I was told in November I had a 3 month wait. I was devastated! I wanted nothing more than to return to my sports. I wanted to be fit and to be able to write long essays required in matriculation. Being a plastics unit, skin cancers get high priority and I have no problems with that as I understand the dangers being an outside person. My father is on a disability pension and my mother cares for him. They are unable to spare the $500 to go private.

speech.para: There are so many disrupted lives as a result of waits for elective surgery.

Another symptom of the crisis in our public hospitals is the growing number of ambulance diversions. Ambulance diversion occurs when hospitals are unable to cope with more patients and instruct ambulances to drive past their hospital and go to more distant facilities. I wrote to the state minister for emergency services on 13 October seeking the number of occasions and the length of time that each hospital in Adelaide was on ambulance diversion for each month this last year. In his letter the minister admitted that:

quote.para: ... hospital diversion, which was spasmodic in 1999, has become a more frequent and regular occurrence in 2000.

speech.para: Although my letter requested information for every month this last year, the minister only provided figures for September and October. For September, there were 36 instances of diversion, totalling 304 hours. For October, there were 56 instances of diversion, totalling 665 hours. The letter highlighted a new and growing problem:

quote.para: In the month of October, the most lengthy periods of diversions were initiated by private hospitals (532 hours out of a total of 665 hours). During those hours, approximately 700 patients were diverted from their preferred destination, with approximately 30 to 50 per cent being received by the public health system.

speech.para: By the minister's own admission, the problem is worsening; yet he did not commit to fixing the problem—only to `monitor the situation keenly'. Since receiving the minister's letter, I have been monitoring the situation myself. The South Australian Ambulance Service have advised me that they had not tabulated statistics for ambulance diversions before September 2000, indicating that this is an emerging problem. The figures I obtained from them reveal that there was a large increase in ambulance diversions at the end of last winter. There were 36 instances of diversion, totalling 304 hours, in September last year. For October there were 56 instances of diversion, totalling 665 hours. During the quieter month of December—when there is less elective surgery—our hospitals were on ambulance diversion 39 times for a total of 398 hours. In January, South Australia's hospitals switched to ambulance diversion on 41 occasions for a total of 417 hours. January is usually a quiet period. I have real fears for the busy winter months that are approaching, given our health system cannot cope now.

Flinders Medical Centre, the main hospital servicing the southern suburbs, has the second busiest emergency department in Australia. Since September last year it has been on ambulance diversion 13 times for 135 hours. The QEH has been on ambulance diversion 16 times for 193 hours. The crisis last month that forced the RAH to send ambulances on diversion back to the QEH demonstrated that deterioration because, under current arrangements, the RAH is expected to always be open to receive ambulance diversions.

Hospitals generally get busy at the same time and, therefore, hospitals are commonly on ambulance diversion at the same time. According to information I have obtained for the month of October, there were eight occasions when three hospitals were on ambulance diversion, at least two occasions when four hospitals were on ambulance diversion and one occasion when five hospitals were on ambulance diversion. Wakefield Hospital and St Andrew's Hospital were both on ambulance diversion at the same time on 15 occasions. It is important to make the point that there are only nine hospitals in the Adelaide metropolitan area, some of which are not suitable to receive emergency patients.

The ambulance service has also provided me with examples of where patient care could have been jeopardised or major stress caused to families by ambulance diversions. In November last year, an Aldinga Beach resident suffering chest pains was taken by ambulance past the FMC, which was on diversion, and on to the Royal Adelaide Hospital. Suspected heart attack patients need urgent hospital care. Patients in these circumstances could easily be having a silent myocardial infarction which would not be detected on the three-lead electrocardiograph in the ambulance. Accurate diagnosis requires a 12-lead ECG. Such patients also need urgent blood tests to determine whether enzymes have been released into the blood stream, indicating the degree of injury to the heart and the appropriate treatment. Drugs to treat blood clots need to be administered as early as possible—preferably within the first hour of the event—and bypassing a major hospital means increasing the time before treatment and reducing the effectiveness of the treatment.

In another incident, an Elizabeth woman who had been assaulted and was unconscious was diverted past the Lyell McEwen and Modbury hospitals to the RAH. The confusion caused police officers to take the woman's children to the Lyell McEwen Hospital where they thought she had been admitted. In another case, a psychiatric patient living at Somerton Park required immediate assessment. The patient should have been assessed by a psychiatrist at Flinders and readied for transport to Glenside. Instead, the patient was diverted to the RAH. By the time the ambulance arrived there, the patient was out of their acute psychotic phase and then spent eight hours in the emergency department, utilising scarce bed space when that could have been avoided.

In another incident, an elderly patient from Victor Harbor requiring hospitalisation for a chronic condition was diverted past Flinders Medical Centre. For those unaware of Adelaide's geography, they would already have been travelling for an hour. As the patient had private health insurance, arrangements were then made to go to Ashford.
