talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) When did the Indonesian Government notify the UN in East Timor of their request for assistance in evacuating UN staff from Atambua in West Timor in early September.
(2) What was the precise content of this request.
(3) Once this request was received by the UN in Dili, to which (a) elements of the UN Peace Keeping Forces and (b) individuals was it passed.

(4) Was this request passed to the Australian Government; if so, (a)when was this done, (b) to whom was it passed in the first instance, (c) who considered this request and decided on the response, (d) when was it replied to, (e) what was the content of the reply, (f) to whom in East Timor was the reply delivered and (g) (i) when and by what chain of command was this reply conveyed to Australian field units in East Timor and (ii) what did those units then do in response.
(5) What role did (a) Australian units and (b) New Zealand units play in the evacuation of UN staff.

(6) What policy and procedures govern Australian military responses to situations such as that which arose from the request for the evacuation of UN staff from Atambua; were those policies and procedures followed in that instance and have they subsequently been changed; if so, in what respect.

(7) Apart from a request from the Indonesian Government was there also a request for assistance from the UNHCR itself on the day of the Atambua murders; if so, what was the request, (b) when was that request made, (c) by whom was it made, (d) to whom in the UNTAET was it delivered, (e) when was it conveyed to the UNPKF, (f) when was it conveyed to (i) Australian military units in East Timor and (ii) to the Australian Government, and (g) what was the Australian response.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: All timings are local East Timor time (that is Dili is two hours behind Canberra).

(1) It is not known if a formal request from the Indonesian Government was received by the United Nations (UN) in East Timor. However, MAJGEN Kikki Syahnakri (COMD KODAM IX) requested UNTAET assistance in dealing with the situation in Atambua on 6 September 2000.
(2) The specific detail of any such requests made to the UN on 6 and 7 September 2000 is unknown.
(3) Once a request was received by the UN in Dili:
(a) it was passed to the FC PKF, who tasked Commander Sector West (COMSECWEST) to plan for an extraction of UNHCR personnel in Atambua.
(b) On 6 September 2000 initial HQ PKF communication with Sector West was between FC PKF and Commander Sector West and their staff.
On 7 September 2000 the FC again tasked COMSECWEST with planning to evacuate the remaining personnel in Atambua.
(4) Information passed to the Australian Government is as follows:
(a) Information was passed on 6 September 2000 to and 7 September 2000:

answer.para: · At 4pm 6 September 2000 the Commander of the Australian Contingent (COMASC) contacted Commander Australian Theatre (COMAST) and requested 1 Light Observation Helicopter (Kiowa) be approved to assist the Sector West extraction operation. This deployment of Australian personnel into West Timor was not approved by COMAST.

· At 4.05 pm 6 September 2000 COMASC contacted COMAST and requested an Australian linguist be approved to assist the Sector West extraction operation. This deployment of an Australian person into West Timor was not approved by COMAST.

· At 5.40 pm 6 September 2000 COMASC contacted COMAST with Commander Sector West request for 2 AUSBATT Platoons, ASLAV Troop and APC elements to be as a contingency in the event any NZAVN elements crashed in East Timor. This request was subsequently cancelled.

· At 10.15 am 7 September 2000 COMASC submitted formal written request to COMAST for Australian assistance to Sector West planning for evacuation of remaining personnel in Atambua noting a H-Hour of not before 2 pm on 7 September 2000.

quote.para: (b) Commander Sector West passed these requests to COMASC, who passed them on to COMAST.
(c) 7 September 2000 request was passed COMASC/COMAST/HSC to the Minister. A/CDF, who was in Adelaide, was briefed on the contents of the request.
(d) Responses were made on 6 and 7 September 2000 to the two separate requests:

answer.para: · At 4.20 pm on 6 September 2000 COMAST informed COMASC that the LOH support was not approved. Commander Sector West was immediately informed.
· At 4.28 pm on 6 September 2000 COMAST informed COMASC that the Australian Linguist support was not approved. COMMANDER SECTOR WEST was immediately informed.

· At 1.35 pm on 7 September 2000 COMAST informed COMASC that the LOH, 3 Blackhawks, 10 security personnel and 1 linguist were approved to support the Sector West plan for evacuation. By 1.45 pm on 7 September 2000 FC PKF, Commander Sector West and CO AUSBATT had been informed of the approval.

quote.para: (e) As in part (d) above.
(f) The reply was delivered as follows:

answer.para: · 6 September 2000. COMASC who then contacted Commander Sector West.
· 7 September 2000. COMASC who then contacted FC PKF, Commander Sector West and CO AUSBATT.

quote.para: (g)(i) Replies were conveyed to the Australian field units in East Timor. 6 Sep 00: LOH: Timings as above and from ASNCE to Headquarters Sector West to 161 Recce Sqn Det. Australian Linguist: Timings as above and from ASNCE to Sector West direct to linguist (Sector West staff officer). 7 September 2000: Timings as above direct from Australian National Command Element East Timor to HQ PKF, Sector West and AUSBATT.

(ii) 6 September 2000: Acknowledged that approval was not given. The Linguist was removed from the NZAVN aircraft and the LOH was tasked with providing support from within East Timor air space. 7 September 2000: Acknowledged that approval was given for the air assets and continued planning for the evacuation operation.
(5)(a) Australian unit roles in the evacuation of UN staff were:

answer.para: · 6 September 2000. An LOH provided limited air command and control from within East Timor air space for CO NZBATT. AUSBATT provided reception, security, clothing, processing and medical attention between 5.45 pm and 9.00 pm on 6 September 2000 at Balibo. Non-Australian UN air assets transported 36 evacuees from Balibo to Dili.

· 7 September 2000. At 3.45 pm on 7 September 2000 a TNI led and escorted road convoy arrived at JP-A (Batugade). AUSBATT soldiers provided reception, security, clothing, processing and medical attention between 3.45 pm and 6.00 pm on 7 September 2000 at JP-A until the 69 persons and 3 mortal remains were taken to Dili by Non-Australian UN air assets.

quote.para: (b) Three New Zealand helicopters (UH1H aircraft) and a detachment of 10 security personnel deployed to Atambua, leaving Suai at 5.00 pm on 6 September 2000. First lift arrived in Balibo at 5.47 pm on 6 September 2000 and the second and final lift arrived in Balibo at 5.56 pm on 6 September 2000. The aircraft then returned to Suai.

(6) Australian Government policy requires that Australian forces are not to be employed outside of the agreed Areas of Operations. Australian forces are not to be used for purposes other than as agreed between the Australian Government and the UN, without prior approval from the Australian Government. The Area of Operations is defined in the CDF's Executive Orders and Rules of Engagement. Missions, limitations, policy and procedures for Australian military responses are included in CDF's and COMAST's Instructions and Directives to the National Commander of the Australian Contingent. Policies and procedures were followed when the request for the evacuation of UN staff from Atambua was received. Planning proceeded as indicated but no action was taken prior to approval. There has been no subsequent change to these policies or procedures.

(7) Currently unaware of any such request being made. Any request is likely to have been to UNTAET, not the Australian Government. Such a request did not come through ASNCE or Headquarters Australian Theatre.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 1 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many resolutions have been carried by the Sydney Airport Community Forum since its formation in 1996.
(2) How many resolutions have been supported by the Government with action.
(3) What were the resolutions referred to in part (2).

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's three questions is as follows:

quote.para: I am advised that eighty-three resolutions had been carried by the SACF up to (and including) the twenty-seventh meeting held on 15 November 2000.

Of these resolutions, some sought more than one action outcome, some sought similar outcomes to those sought in earlier resolutions, some expressed a general viewpoint (without an explicit action proposal), some were procedural in nature and some involved a combination of the above.

Of the discrete action outcomes specifically sought by the resolutions, close to half have been implemented or have been accepted for implementation. Examples of significant actions which the Government has taken in response to, or with the support of, SACF include:

answer.para: · introduction of the noise sharing arrangements established under the Sydney Airport Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP)
· inclusion in the LTOP of provision for use of Simultaneous Opposite Direction Parallel Runway Operations
· introduction of ICAO `A' departure procedures for Runways 34 Left and Right
· introduction of the legislated movement cap
· no amendments to the movement cap or the curfew during the Olympics
· Commonwealth funding for Sydenham open space and community facility development
· introduction of the `out to sea' SID [Standard Instrument Departure] to the south of the Airport
· enhanced reporting and provision of information on the Airport's runway and flight path movements
· the location of a permanent noise monitoring terminal in Croydon
· the purchase of additional mobile noise monitoring terminals for use in Sydney
· regulations imposing penalties for fuel venting from aircraft
· exclusion of older aircraft accessing the Airport during the curfew
· ensuring Sydney Airport air traffic takes priority over Bankstown traffic
· requirement for regular SACL reporting to SACF
· deferral of implementation of the Precision Runway Monitor on Runways 16 prior to a full environmental assessment being conducted.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Does the web site of the Federal Magistrates Service advertise the existence of a Magistrate based in Launceston.
(2) Is it normal practice for Federal Courts to publicise the existence of a judge or magistrate when the official is yet to be appointed.
(3) Will he ensure that the web site of the Federal Magistrates Service accurately reflects the Government's progress in appointing a Magistrate to Launceston.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) On 16 November I announced the appointment of Mr Stuart Roberts as the first federal magistrate for Launceston. At that time, I indicated that Mr Roberts would take up his position on 4 December 2000. As at 4 December 2000, the web site of the Federal Magistrates Service indicated that Mr Roberts commenced his appointment on 4 December. Before that time the web site noted that family law matters for the Federal Magistrates Service could be filed in the Launceston registry of the Family Court.

(2) On 31 of January 2000, I announced the proposed locations of the federal magistrates. That announcement included the fact that the Government intended to locate a federal magistrate in Launceston. In these circumstances, it was entirely appropriate for the Federal Magistrates Service to indicate that a federal magistrate would be appointed who would be resident in Launceston.

(3) See question 1. The web site of the Federal Magistrates Service now indicates that Mr Roberts took up his position on 4 December. It also includes my press release of 11 December noting that Mr Roberts would start hearing cases from 11 December. The web site has accurately reflected the position regarding the appointment of a federal magistrate at all times.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) For the latest year for which data is available, how many recruits to the Army Reserve completed Common Induction Training.

(2) Of those referred to in part (1), how many were (a) full time students, (b) unemployed, (c) self employed, (d) employed in the private sector, (e) employed by State or local government and (f) employed by the Federal Government.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) 1300 Part Time soldiers were trained in Training Year 99/00 of which 1167 have successfully completed the requirements of the 45 day Army Recruit Course. 23 Part Time soldiers have been inducted in Training Year 00/01 and are at various points along the training continuum. This result is equivalent to that for the same point in Training Years 98/99 and 99/00.

(2) A detailed breakdown by pre-induction employment is not possible from the database maintained by the Army Recruit Training Centre. A significant research task would be necessary to extract the necessary information.
No one group dominates the intake population, however, students are a significant component of the Part Time recruit population in the period December to February.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission: Chairman
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2117)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 2 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Was he, his staff or his Department consulted by the Chairman of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) concerning the Chairman's decision to write for the Business Review Weekly every four weeks.
(2) What is the nature of the ACCC Chairman's appointment and what are the details of the Chairman's remuneration package.
(3) Will the Chairman of the ACCC write for the journal every four weeks, covering any subject he chooses, as reported in the BRW on 20 October.
(4) Has the Government developed guidelines or held discussions with Professor Fels about his position and the type of subjects on which he chooses to write.
(5) Will Professor Fels be required to declare publicly any financial benefit he receives for writing for the BRW.
(6) Given Professor Fels' heavy workload as reflected in the ACCC annual report 1999-2000, will his remuneration package be discounted for any earnings he receives from the BRW.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (2) Professor Fels was appointed from 6 November 2000 until 30 June 2004 on the same terms and conditions as applied to his initial term as ACCC Chairman, until the Remuneration Tribunal determines otherwise. His remuneration package totals $250,000. This includes a base salary of $179,500 and an office holder supplement of $11,500 as determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. He has access to the usual superannuation and leave arrangements for the holder of a statutory office at his salary level, a private plated vehicle, home telephone reimbursement and spouse travel.
(3) Professor Fels will write for the BRW every four weeks. He intends to write mainly about trade practices and competition issues.
(4) There have been no discussions with Professor Fels about him writing for the BRW.

The ACCC is required under the Trade Practices Act 1974 to disseminate information with respect to the carrying out of the functions, or the exercise of the powers, of the ACCC under the Act. Therefore, it is not uncommon for Professor Fels and other ACCC members to write articles for a variety of publications from time to time.
(5) Professor Fels will not receive any financial benefit for writing for BRW. He did not seek any financial benefit, nor was he offered any financial benefit.
(6) Not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has the Government yet finalised its response to the August 1997 Abadee report into the judicial independence of military trials; if not, what is the reason for the delay.
(2) Which of Brigadier Abadee's 48 recommendations have been (a) accepted in full by the Government, (b) rejected in part and (c) rejected in full.

(3) Did the 1999 annual report of the Judge Advocate General indicate that proposed legislation responding to the Abadee Report had been forwarded to Service Chiefs for comment; if so, what is the current status of this proposed legislation.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Some of the recommendations require implementation by administrative action only. Such action will be finalised by the issue of the next amendment to the Discipline Law Manuals. Drafting instructions are being prepared with regard to those recommendations that require amendment of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982, its regulations or rules.
(2)(a) The Department of Defence has accepted, or agreed in principle to, 38 recommendations; as follows:
RECOMMENDATIONS AGREED OR AGREED IN PRINCIPLE BY DEFENCE

entry.para: Standard of Military Justice should not vary between war and peace.
Multiple roles of Convening Authorities (CA) should be eliminated

Court martial (CM) / Defence Force magistrate(DFM) prosecutions decisions: prosecution policy similar to those in operation in various States or the Commonwealth (with suitable modifications) should be introduced

Retain the present system of the Judge Advocate General (JAG) nominating officers to the Judge Advocate's (JA's) panel, appointing DFMs and recommending the appointment of DFDA s154(1)(a) reporting officers to provide legal reports in respect of DFM/CM convictions.
No command or control (other than administrative) should be exercised over JAs, DFMs and DFDA s154(1)(a) reporting officers in respect of their judicial duties
JAA should be under command of JAG.
No reporting on JAs, DFMs and DFDA s154(1)(a) reporting officers in respect of their judicial duties
Separate administrative authority in respect of the non-judicial duties of JAs, DFMs and DFDA s154(1)(a) reporting officers
Duties of a judicial nature, including the appointment of a JA, DFM for a particular trial, or the nomination of a 154(1)(a) reporting officer, be allocated by JAA
Convening orders issued by CAs should include a request for the JAG to appoint a JA or DFM, or alternatively, a statement that a particular JA/DFM has been appointed by the JAG.
Fixed term tenure for JAs/DFMs and DFDA s154(1)(a) reporting officers
JA's DFMs and DFDA s154(1)(a) reporting officers should be permitted to perform non-judicial duties
Consideration should be given to the establishment of a Courts Administration Unit, independent of the CA (outside the chain of command and reporting chains)

A CA should wherever possible appoint persons from outside his command, outside his reporting chain and outside his unit with selection perhaps being from a large, tri-Service, pool of suitable officers.
Reviews of CM proceedings and DFM trials should be conducted by an authority other than the CA.
Prohibit reference to officer's performance as member of CM when determining pay, appointment or efficiency reporting
Consideration should be given to the question of whether a JA should be involved in sentencing.
Further consideration should be given to whether JA should give reasons for punishment.
No right of appeal by prosecutors in respect of sentence
Consideration should be given to the inclusion of a `no conviction' option in respect of an offence charged under the Act
No action should be taken to provide appeal rights in respect of CO/SUBSA convictions
The present review system is efficacious and provides appropriate protections.
Disadvantages of appeals from decisions of summary authorities outweighs advantages
Redress inexperience of some DFDA s154(1)(b) legal officers addressed by training, secondment to DPP, and use of Reserves.

Re elective punishments, provision should be made for the election to be in writing and for the summary authority to furnish to the accused certain explanations about the election when giving him the opportunity to elect trial by DFM or CM.

Training of summary authorities, prosecuting and defending officers including publication of sentencing statistics and guidelines and legal principles contained in legal reports by JAG/DJAG and DFDA s154(1)(a) officers.
No change recommended in respect of the present system of reporting on COs in relation to their performance of duties in maintaining and enforcing discipline
No reporting in respect of performance of duties by CO as a service tribunal in a particular case

quote.para: (b) The Department of Defence has partially agreed to one recommendation, as follows:
RECOMMENDATIONS PARTIALLY ACCEPTED BY DEFENCE

entry.para: Extension of discipline officer system to include officers of up to and including the rank of MAJ(E)
Extension of discipline officer system to include officers of up to and including the rank of CAPT(E) under training

quote.para: (c) The Department of Defence has disagreed with nine recommendations; as follows:
RECOMMENDATIONS REJECTED BY DEPARTMENT

entry.para: Appointment of an independent Director of Military Prosecutions on a tri-Service basis
Appointment of an independent Director of Military Prosecutions on a tri-Service basis
Confer rights of appeal in relation to sentences imposed by CM/DFM.
Give further consideration to conferring rights of appeal against decisions of COs especially when elective punishments are involved
DFDA s154(1)(b) legal officers should be independent of the prosecution process and of the reviewing authority.[Initial agreement withdrawn because of practical implementation problems]
Remove reduction in rank as an elective punishment

quote.para: (3) The annual report to Parliament for the period 1 January to 31 December 1999 submitted by the Judge Advocate General stated that `...the proposal for a Miscellaneous Defence Legislation Amendment Bill incorporating the Abadee recommendations has been forwarded to the Service chiefs for comment.' Drafting instructions are being prepared to enable the amendment of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982, its regulations or rules.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) When did work commence on the development of an Australian Defence Force Prosecution Policy.
(2) Is a key requirement of the policy the need to ensure that military commanders exercise their discretion to prosecute fairly, appropriately and consistently.
(3) Has the proposed policy been finalised and promulgated: if so, on what date did this occur; if not, what is the reason for the delay.
(4) What reporting to Parliament is envisaged concerning actual compliance with the provisions of the policy.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Work commenced on the development of an ADF Prosecution Policy in July 1998.

(2) The policy guides commanding officers in the exercise of their discretion by setting out applicable principles and a non-exhaustive list of factors to be considered. One of these factors states that “As a general rule, the discretion to prosecute should be exercised consistently and fairly with similar cases being dealt with in a similar way. However, it must always be recognised that no two cases are identical and there is always a requirement to consider the unique circumstances and facts of each case before deciding whether to prosecute.”
(3) The policy instruction Defence Instruction (General) Personnel 45-4 Australian Defence Force Prosecution Policy was issued on 29 August 2000.
(4) The policy instruction does not require the formulation of compliance reports and, consequently, does not require any such reports to be submitted to Parliament.

subdebateinfo.title: Vietnam Veterans: Civilian Surgical and Medical Teams
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2138)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 7 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a recommendation from Major General Mohr in an independent report stating that Australian civilian surgical and medical teams operating in Vietnam during the Vietnam War be deemed as performing qualifying service for repatriation benefits.
(2) How many Australian civilian surgical and medical teams who served in Vietnam were awarded the Australian Active Service Medal (AASM).

(3) Were Australian civilian surgical and medical officers who served in Vietnam awarded an AASM on the basis that they were integrated with the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and performed like functions with their ADF counterparts.
(4) Will he amend the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 2000 to allow Australian civilian surgical and medical teams access to repatriation benefits; if not, why not.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(3) No. The Australian civilian surgical and medical officers were awarded the AASM on the basis that they were an important part of the Australian aid effort in South Vietnam. They were not bound by military discipline or orders and therefore not under military command.

(4) No. The members of civilian surgical and medical teams who worked in Vietnam were employed by the then Department of External Affairs under a South East Asia Treaty Organisation (SEATO) aid program.

Their contract of employment specified that they were covered for compensation purposes under Commonwealth employees' compensation legislation, now the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988.

Therefore the Government takes the view that compensation coverage is available for the nurses and that if there are issues to be resolved about that cover they should be resolved within the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 and not by recourse to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 8 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is it a fact that the 1995-1996 Labor Government Budget allocated funds to the Commonwealth Financial Counselling Program in Queensland of $477 429, and in the 1996-1997 Coalition Budget this was cut to $416 840.

(2) Is it a fact that the Coalition Budgets of 1997-98, 1998-99, 1999-2000 and 2000-2001 allocated to the Commonwealth Financial Counselling Program in Queensland $414 800, $415 590, $416 190 and $459 640, respectively.
(3) While there was an increase in the allocation to Queensland from 1999-2000 to 2000-2001, is the current budget allocation still below that of 1995-1996 in dollar terms and real dollar terms.
(4) Did Network Australia undertake a cost benefit analysis of the Program in 1998 which showed that the Program's measurable benefits exceed its costs.
(5) Did Network Australia also indicate that it would be next to impossible for a commercial provider to provide the same level and quality of service as the existing non-profit agencies.
(6) What steps are being taken to ensure that agencies are adequately funded and viable.
(7) What administrative support is the Government giving to agencies.
(8) Is the Government using the information obtained by the agencies to inform public policy on issues such as bankruptcy and related consumer credit issues, if so, how.
(9) Is the Government working cooperatively with the agencies to assist them to develop viable funding models.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) In 1995-96, a total of $497,429 was paid to 6 financial counselling services in Queensland under the Commonwealth Financial Counselling Program. About $45,000 out of this total were one-off payments for start-up costs of two new services. In 1996-97, total funding was $416,840 [without any start-up costs or one-off payments].
(2) Funding for the 6 financial counselling services in Queensland under the Commonwealth Financial Counselling Program for the period 1997-98 to 2000-2001 was:
(3) The current year's [2000-2001] total allocation for the Commonwealth Financial Counselling Program is $2.21 million while the total allocation in 1995-96 was $2.19 million.

(4) Network Australia Organisational Consulting Group in Brisbane conducted a cost-benefit analysis of the Program in 1998 at the request of the then Department of Industry, Science and Tourism which was the Program administrator at the time. The analysis concluded that the Program's measurable benefits exceed its costs.

(5) Network Australia's cost-benefit analysis also concluded that the estimated cost for a commercial provider to run the same level of service would be $3.25 million compared with the actual cost of about $2.20 million under the Program.
(6) The Program administrator has always maintained close communication with the funded agencies and the national Senior Casework Officer/Facilitator on funding matters.

(7) Since 1996, the Program has been funding a Senior Casework Officer/Facilitator to assist the financial counsellors in their casework and to facilitate the resolution of any issues that may arise between the financial counsellors and the agency management. From time to time the Government, as Program administrator, also assists in the implementation of new initiatives for the Program, e.g. in 1998 the Government assisted the agencies in implementing their client service charter.

(8) Each agency is required to provide quarterly statistics on service provision. The information collected includes problems confronting clients, sources of income/income level, sources of referral, gender, family composition and others. In addition, agencies also provide annual appraisal reports on their operations. This information has been provided from time to time to other Government agencies, including Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia, to assist in policy formulation relating to bankruptcy and consumer credit issues.
(9) The Government, as Program administrator, has always worked cooperatively with the agencies on funding issues affecting their services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 8 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) In accordance with the terms of the Airports Act, when will the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) commence its five year Regulatory Review of the airport privatisation process.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the concern from airport owners that the ACCC does not have the depth or intricate knowledge of the day to day dynamics of running an airport, nor the ability to foresee the impact of operational and technological advances in the industry; if so, is it appropriate that the ACCC review its own continuing role in regulating the industry.

(3) Does the Government accept that there is a fundamental contradictory flaw in having a regulator such as the ACCC conduct a review of its own continuing role in regulating the industry, rather than an alternative body such as the Productivity Commission.
(4) Will the airport owners be consulted about the Regulatory Review and the terms of reference of the review.
(5) Will the Civil Aviation Safety Authority or the Australian Transport Safety Bureau play any role in the Regulatory Review.
(6) Will the terms of reference be publicly available.
(7) Will any party be open to make submissions to the review.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) to (7) The Government has decided that the Productivity Commission will undertake the review of prices oversight arrangements at airports. There are strong synergies between this review and the Productivity Commission's current review of the Prices Surveillance Act 1983, which provides the framework within which airport prices are regulated. There are also synergies with its current reviews of telecommunications specific competition regulation and access arrangements under Part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act 1974.

The Government sent terms of reference to the Productivity Commission on 21 December 2000. The Commission will shortly release an issues paper and invite expressions of interest from anyone wanting to participate in the review. The terms of reference are publicly available.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1925 (Hansard, 2 November 2000, page 19584), were the last medical reports provided to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) about the state of health of former Senator Malcolm Arthur Colston provided on 7 April 1999; if not, (a) how many medical reports have been submitted to the DPP since 7 April 1999 and (b) what are the dates of these medical reports.

(2) Since the Media Statement titled “Prosecution of Malcolm Colston”, dated 5 July 1999 which declared that there is no prospect that former Senator Colston will be fit to stand trial in the future, has the DPP's attention been drawn to reports that former Senator Colston has been observed (a) sitting in the audience of the television show “The New Price is Right”, (b) dining out in Brisbane restaurants, (c) shopping in Brisbane, (d) travelling within and outside Queensland, (e) providing an interview to the media and (f) engaging in correspondence with the print media.

(3) In light of the above reports on the activities of former Senator Colston since 5 July 1999 and further to the answer to question No. 1925 that, if there was evidence contrary to the earlier advice that former Senator Colston was not fit to stand trial and there was no prospect that he would be fit to stand trial in the future, will the DPP obtain fresh medical opinions on the current state of health of Mr Colston.
(4) Are the current DPP Prosecution Policies based on the UK Royal Commission on Criminal Procedure, chaired by Sir Cyril Philips, dated January 1981.

(5) Does he accept the view put forward in paragraph 6.10 at page 128 of the report referred to in part (4) that it is a material consideration of a criminal justice system that the proper objective of a fair prosecution system is not simply to prosecute the guilty and avoid prosecuting the innocent but rather to ensure that prosecutions are initiated only in those cases in which there is adequate evidence and where prosecution is justified in the public interest.

(6) Does the report further note at paragraph 6.11 at page 129 that the ability of any prosecution system to take account of these considerations of humanity (viz. age, sex, physical and mental condition (of the defendant)) and of other elements of public interest is a hallmark of fairness, provided that such criteria are applied consistently.

(7) Does the application of the Information Privacy Principles in the way they have been applied to this matter and in the matter of Christopher Skase in the prosecution of justice, combine to produce inconsistency in procedural decision making.

(8) Is leaving sole responsibility in the hands of the DPP in deciding whether to continue or discontinue proceedings precisely the kind of “lacking effective machinery for achieving conformity in prosecution policies” referred to a paragraph 6.46 on page 138 in the UK report.
(9) Are the standards applied in weighing these considerations inconsistent with weigh to such factors given by the DPP's pursuit of the prosecution of Mr Christopher Skase.
(10) Further to the answers to parts (4) and (10) of question No. 1925, are both the policy considerations of adequacy of evidence and justification in the public interest satisfied.

(11) Is the last available medical evidence now some nineteen months old; if so, does the weight of policy considerations in obtaining further evidence in determining whether to direct the DPP to resume prosecution now outweigh policy considerations that medically preclude former Senator Colston from standing trial.
(12) Have the compassionate grounds upon which this prosecution was terminated now been exhausted and should fresh evidence be called.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No. (a) and (b) Apart from reports which the DPP has obtained from medical experts consulted by the DPP, the DPP has been provided with one medical report by Dr Colston's solicitors dated 23 November 2000.
(2)(a) to ( e) Yes.

(3) Yes. The prosecution was discontinued because Dr Colston was not fit to stand trial and there was no prospect that he would be fit to stand trial in the future. The DPP is in the process of reviewing this position.
(4) No, although the report of this Royal Commission was part of the material considered in preparing the Prosecution Policy of the Commonwealth.
(5) Yes (Note: this is at paragraph 6.9 of the Report)
(6) Yes.
(11) No. See 3.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith Airport): Aircraft Approach Trial
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2154)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 27 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has the Government's attention been drawn to a low-noise approach technique proposed by Ansett involving aircraft on descent into Sydney using minimum power, thereby potentially making less noise until aircraft reach an altitude of 1000 feet; if so, will this proposal be considered as part of the current trial of the new Precision Runway Monitoring System and will that testing include consideration of whether the proposal helps minimise greenhouse emissions.

(2) Has Airservices Australia or the Civil Aviation Safety Authority conducted any separate analysis or safety assessment of the technique referred to in part (1) or any similar system; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am aware of the Ansett proposal to trial “power-off” approaches using a Standard Terminal Arrival Route (STAR) at Sydney Airport. Following receipt of advice from the Sydney Airport Community Forum, I have advised the Forum of my view that an evaluation of the STAR approach should be deferred until after Environment Australia has completed the current trial of the Precision Runway Monitor System.

(2) I am advised that Airservices Australia has developed a procedure to be used in trialing “power-off” STAR approaches for northerly arrivals at Sydney Airport. This was drawn up in accordance with Airservices Australia's standard practices for developing new operating procedures.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 27 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No 1797 (Hansard, 6 November 2000, page 19674) in which he quotes Mr Corrigan as saying that since the Government's most recent waterfront reform, stevedoring charges have declined, has the increase in productivity due to higher crane lift rates and the reduction in the workforce led to the declining charges.
(2) Are importers and exporters paying the same stevedoring rates, and in some cases higher rates, as they were paying prior to the waterfront reform; if so, why.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's (ACCC) October 2000 Container Stevedore Monitoring report concluded that stevedoring charges were $173 per teu for the January to June 2000 period. This compares with $181 per teu for the period February to June 1999 and $203 per teu in 1995. Therefore, between 1995 and 2000 there has been a 15 per cent reduction in the aggregate stevedoring charge.

The ACCC report also states that during the period July 1999 to June 2000 the stevedoring industry was going through a period of transition with revenue per teu falling but marked increases in productivity.

The improvement in productivity was reflected in the December 2000 issue of Waterline which reported record waterfront performance for the September quarter 2000 with a five-port average crane rate of 24.9 containers per hour, the highest level achieved since the series commenced. This compares with the pre-Patrick dispute five-port average crane rate of 18.7 containers per hour.
The five-port average ship rate was also an all time record at 38 containers per hour for the September quarter 2000, well above the pre-Patrick dispute figure of 24.3 containers per hour.
(2) Refer to answer in question (1) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 23 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) What consultations and negotiations did the Government conduct with Mitsubishi prior to its decision in 1997 to freeze car tariffs?
(2) As part of the process referred to in part (1), did Mitsubishi give certain undertakings regarding the future of its car production operations in Australia: if so, what are the details?
(3) How many people are employed in the Australian car manufacturing industry?

(3) What sums are provided in (a) direct subsidies and support, (b) import protection and (c) other indirect assistance to the car manufacturing industry by (i) the Commonwealth Government and (ii) State Governments?

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The Government consulted closely with each of the Australian car manufacturers, including Mitsubishi Motors Australia Limited (MMAL), prior to its decision in 1997 to freeze car tariffs at 15 per cent between 1 January 2000 and 31 December 2004.
(2) No specific undertakings were given by MMAL or other car makers to the Government as a result of the 1997 decision to freeze car tariffs.

(3) Data held by the Department of Industry, Science and Resources indicates that in December 1999 there were 21,394 people employed in the Australian car manufacturing industry. The most recent data published by the ABS indicates there were a further 30,077 people employed in the automotive components industry in 1999.

(4)(a) Under the Duty Free Allowance (DFA) arrangements, vehicle producers were entitled to import 15 per cent of their value of production duty free. Duty forgone in 1999 under the DFA was $192.6 million. The Export Facilitation Scheme (EFS) allowed participants to earn export credits in return for automotive exports and to use these credits to offset the duty on their imports. Duty forgone in 1999 under the EFS was $262.3 million. The DFA and EFS arrangements ended on 31 December 2000.

The Automotive Competitiveness and Investment Scheme (ACIS), which commenced on 1 January 2001, is encouraging the development of internationally competitive firms in the automotive industry through the provision of import duty credits to reward eligible production, strategic investment and research and development. The full value of ACIS, including the former DFA, will be over $2 billion over its five year term.
(b) A 15 per cent tariff applies to imports of passenger motor vehicles and components. The rate will fall to 10 per cent on 1 January 2005.

(c) The Automotive Market Access and Development Strategy provides support to the industry through the services of a market access facilitator in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the placement of industry specialists in the Detroit, Frankfurt, Tokyo and Bangkok offices of Austrade. Firms in the automotive industry may also benefit from a range of non-industry specific assistance measures, such as the research and development tax concession, R&D Start, the Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program, the National Office of Information Economy's Information Technology On Line program and others.
The Commonwealth has no record of the amount of assistance provided by state governments to automotive firms.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 December 2000:

quote.para: (1) With respect to the Australian Transport Safety Bureau's (ATSB) Media Alert regarding Australia's record in 1997 as the sixth worst rank amongst OECD nations for annual motorcyclist fatalities, how many road fatalities of motorcycle riders have occurred in (a) 1997, (b) 1998, (c) 1999 and (d) to date in 2000.
(2) What action has the Government taken to improve safety awareness for motorcyclists, motorists and the general public about motorcycle safety.
(3) What amount of the ATSB's budget is allocated to promoting and improving motorcycle safety and how is that budget spent.

(4) How many motorcycle accidents have been investigated by the ATSB in 2000 and have any safety recommendations for improvements resulted from those investigations; if so, have they been implemented.

(5) Are there any national standards, programs or campaigns being pursued by the National Road Transport Commission or the Australian Transport Council that relate to strategies to reduce the number of motorcyclist fatalities; if so, what are they.
(6) Are there any Australian Design Standards for road construction or maintenance that enhance the safety of motorcyclists.
(7) Which Department, agency or authority is responsible to ensure that National Highways meet design standards and how is that responsibility fulfilled.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The number of motorcyclist fatalities from road crashes in Australia (including pillion passengers) in 1997 was 177; in 1998 was 181; in 1999 was 176; and in 2000 was 191.

(2) The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) chairs a Motorcycle Safety Consultative Committee, which provides a forum for constructive consultation between the Federal Government and key stakeholder groups on national motorcycle safety issues. The committee normally meets twice a year in Canberra.

In 1998-99 the ATSB, in consultation with the Motorcycle Safety Consultative Committee, developed a new safety education video for novice motorcycle riders. A booklet was also produced to complement the video. The video was duplicated and its availability was advertised during 1999-2000. Requests for the video have come from all parts of Australia and over 15 000 copies have been distributed.

The ATSB has provided a free copy of the video to all public libraries with video lending facilities across Australia. All motorcycle clubs and associations have had advertising brochures direct mailed to them. The ATSB offered the video at cost price to all motorcycle trainers.

Other safety materials developed by the ATSB and its predecessor, the Federal Office of Road Safety (FORS), in consultation with the Motorcycle Safety Consultative Committee include a poster, brochure and card. The major message of the material is that safety on the roads for motorcyclists is the joint responsibility of all road users. The ATSB direct mailed multiple copies of the materials to all motorcycle clubs and associations around Australia. This year, the ATSB provided 60 000 copies of the brochures to the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority for direct mail out with renewing registrations during Motorcycle Awareness Week.

In 1996, FORS conducted a national outdoor advertising campaign aimed at raising motorcycle safety awareness among both riders and drivers. The campaign featured billboard advertisements with informative messages tailored to each group of road users. A total of 493 billboards, positioned at service stations and major intersections around Australia, were used to display four separate messages addressing different aspects of rider and driver behaviour.

A subsequent evaluation of the campaign found that the strategy was successful in communicating with both road user groups, achieving a national awareness rate of 32% (considered very high for this advertising medium).
Annual statistical reports and monthly statistical bulletins produced by the ATSB and by FORS give explicit treatment to motorcyclist casualty data.
These regular outputs are augmented by statistical monographs dealing with topical road safety issues. The following monographs have been dedicated to motorcyclist road safety issues:

answer.para: · Road risk for sober licensed motorcyclists (FORS Monograph 27, 1999).
· Australia's international motorcycle safety performance 1987-1997 (ATSB Monograph 4, 2000).
· Types of fatal injuries sustained by motorcyclists (ATSB Monograph 6, to be released in early 2001).

quote.para: Between 1997 and 2000, ATSB and FORS released an additional five monographs dealing with the issues of vehicle use by intoxicated or unlicensed motorists. Each of these monographs included specific information about intoxicated or unlicensed motorcyclists.

Another monograph released during this period, Vehicle type and the risk of travelling on the road (FORS Monograph 17, 1997) compared the risk of road casualty between vehicle types, including motorcycles. It included the finding that motorcyclists are 20 times more likely to be killed or admitted to hospital than the drivers of other types of vehicles.

During 1996 and 1997 FORS and Vicroads jointly funded a comprehensive investigation of motorcycle crashes. The aim of the study was to identify risk factors associated with serious injury and fatal motorcycle crashes, in order to contribute to the development of effective countermeasures. Public release of the findings attracted media attention and helped to promote awareness of the safety needs of motorcyclists.
(3) In the 2000-2001 financial year, the ATSB has allocated an estimated $77,500 to promoting and improving motorcycle safety:

answer.para: · $15,000 - for the administration of the Motorcycle Safety Consultative Committee;
· $15,000 - a grant to the NSW Motorcycle Council for television airtime and advertising to promote Motorcycle Awareness Week;
· $24,000 - for staffing and postage costs of distributing motorcycle safety materials and for advertising the availability of the materials;
· $16,000 - for the production of two ATSB monographs dedicated to motorcyclist road safety issues;

· - In addition, ATSB's budget for 2000-2001 included $976,457 for statistical activities covering all road user groups. These activities include the maintenance of databases of road crash data pertaining to all types of road users, the preparation of annual and quarterly statistical reports and the analysis and reporting of data in response to requests for information. These statistical resources are relevant to motorcycle safety, but it is not possible to attribute a specific fraction to motorcycle safety.

· $7,500 - for a study to assess the feasibility and cost of a research program to investigate the interactions between motorcycles and road safety barriers, and to recommend a suitable method. The total cost of this project was $25,000, of which $17,500 was expended before 30 June 2000.

quote.para: (4) The ATSB is not resourced to undertake investigations of individual road crashes; this is done by state and territory police.

(5) The National Road Transport Commission (NRTC) is not currently pursuing any national standards, programs or campaigns that relate specifically to strategies to reduce the number of motorcyclist fatalities. A significant part of the NRTC work program is focused on nationally uniform or consistent regulation of issues concerning heavy vehicles; in addition to the Australian Road Rules and the National Driver Licensing Scheme, which apply to all drivers/riders.

The Australian Transport Council has adopted the National Road Safety Strategy 2001-2010, which aims to dramatically reduce death and injury on Australian roads. The associated National Road Safety Action Plan 2001 and 2002 identifies a menu of Action Areas and measures that are available for implementation. Motorcyclists are identified as one of a number of groups of vulnerable road users, and measures offered in the Action Plan aimed explicitly at improving motorcycle safety include the need to:

answer.para: · Evaluate and, if appropriate, improve motorcycle rider training and licensing schemes.
· Promote improved interaction between motorcyclists and other road users through targeted public education campaigns.
· Ensure that road safety audits take into account motorcycle-specific safety issues.

quote.para: Several other Action Areas in the Strategy and Action Plan will also have benefits for motorcycle safety, in particular those relating to compliance with speed limits, deterrence of unlicensed driving and motorcycling, and improving the safety of existing and new roads.

(6) As part of its `Guide to Traffic Engineering Practice' series, Austroads has published Part 15: Motorcycle Safety, which is intended to provide traffic engineering practitioners with a better understanding of motorcyclists' safety needs.

A revised version of Austroads' Road Safety Audit Guide is to be released soon. The Guide provides practitioners and decision makers in State highway authorities, local government authorities and consulting practices with ways of formally addressing road safety issues during design, before accidents occur. One of the specific aims of conducting road safety audits is more explicit consideration of the safety needs of vulnerable road users, and the guide also provides instructions and checklists for specialist audits for specific road user groups such as motorcyclists. Auditors are encouraged to use the mode of travel in question and consider the safety issues from the user's point of view.

The Australian Standard for Road safety barrier systems (AS/NZS 3845:1999) acknowledges that special measures, such as removing gaps, and/or cushioning or softening parts of barriers, may be necessary where the risk of impact by motorcyclists is unacceptably high.

There are many other standards, design guides and guidelines relating to road design, maintenance and construction, that include safety as a consideration, and these are intended to enhance the safety of all road users including motorcyclists.

(7) The Department of Transport and Regional Services is responsible for ensuring that National Highways meet design standards. In any submission for National Highway funding, State/Territory road authorities are required to provide details of the proposed construction or maintenance to the Department. The submissions are examined for compliance with the National Highway Design Standards as promulgated by the Minister. The Department also conducts field inspections to confirm that the standards have been met.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 7 December 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many hunger strikes and other acts of rebellion by detainees have occurred in immigration detention centres since Australasian Correctional Management (ACM) took control of these centres.
(2) How do the acts referred to in part (1) compare with the period before ACM took over as the private contractor running these facilities.
(3) Is he satisfied that the attitudes of ACM, including its recruitment and personnel strategies, are completely legal and appropriate and have not provoked or exacerbated tensions in the centres.
(4) Is he satisfied that no wrongful actions on the part of ACM or its staff have been responsible for provoking protests by detainees at Woomera Detention Centre.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) “Acts of rebellion” is difficult to define. Detainees express their opposition to detention in a variety of ways, ranging from non-compliance with a request to more serious incidents such as assaults, wilful damage and mass breakouts. The question has therefore been defined within these parameters in order to provide a meaningful response. The data below records incidents rather than the number of individuals participating in an incident. Records kept by ACM for the period from commencement of the contract in December 1997 to the 31 December 1998 would require manual retrieval from files of more than 1100 incident reports for analysis. In the time available, and given the resource intensity of such a task, data for this period has not been included. Since 1 January 1999, records have been stored electronically. For the period 1 January 1999 to 19 December 2000, more than 2215 records have been examined to provide the following information.
ACM Incident Reports 1 January 1999 - 19 December 2000

entry.para: Failure to comply with lawful directions

quote.para: (2) Comparing incident reports kept by APS since the establishment of immigration detention centres until the engagement of ACM in December 1997 with that of ACM, would require manual retrieval from files of more than 4000 incident reports for analysis. As indicated in the response to the first question, due to time and resource constraints, such a task cannot be undertaken at this time. However, using the same parameters adopted in the response to the first question, the following information is provided on the basis of APS incident reports for the period 2 January 1996 - 3 December 1997.
APS Incident Reports: 2 January 1996 - 3 December 1997

entry.para: Failure to comply with lawful directions

quote.para: Comparison of these figures shows the following trend under ACM vis-à-vis APS:

entry.para: Failure to comply with lawful directions

quote.para: While “assault on staff” and “wilful damage to Commonwealth Property” have decreased under ACM, other “acts of rebellion”, including “hunger strike” and “escapes” have increased significantly. This trend is a reflection of increasing non-compliant behaviour by immigration detainees. These “acts of rebellion” also need to be viewed within the context of the number of persons held in detention over the period under review.

The environment within which APS operated and the environment within which ACM operates, are very different. Under APS, there were 4 detention facilities. We now have 6 detention facilities. The population in detention centres under APS was significantly less than current levels. There were more detainee days in 1999 - 2000 than in the three preceding years combined.
The following table shows the number of detainee days for the period 1996 - 2001 (a detainee day refers to a day each immigration detainee spends in detention).

(3) ACM recruitment and personnel strategies are conducted in accordance with the principles of equal opportunity, merit and natural justice. ACM run competency based training courses that include modules to assist their staff to promote the health, welfare and safety of detainees. Refresher courses are run regularly.
(4) There is no evidence to suggest that the major incidents at the Woomera IRPC in 2000 (June breakouts and August riot) were precipitated by the actions of ACM staff.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 7 December 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say what efforts are being made by the four major banks in respect to assisting those affected by floods.
(2) Is he able to say how many more bank branches are to close in Australia in 2001.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Each bank provides a range of assistance for customers who are experiencing difficulties because of the flooding. All of the four majors have decided to freeze interest rate margins on farm loans and not to impose establishment fees on loan restructuring for existing business loans for customers who receive government support.
The ANZ has made a donation of $100,000 to enhance community resources available to help those facing hardship following the flood. ANZ has also announced that:

answer.para: · customers eligible for government assistance can defer principal and interest calls on term loans for 12 months;
· repayments on all loans will be suspended for 3 months;
· withdrawal costs for term deposits and fees associated with restructuring business loans will not be imposed; and
· temporary adjustments to customer lending limits will be considered.

· Commonwealth and Colonial Bank branches are accepting community donations for the Wesley Mission Flood Victim appeal. The Bank is collecting packaged and tinned food and is shipping this to flood affected areas. Teams of Commonwealth Bank staff have also been provided to help clean up affected areas on a fully paid basis. The CBA has also announced that:
· there will be opportunities for flood affected customers to change their repayment arrangements on home loans or they can apply for additional loans;
· the possible postponement of credit card instalments for customers of good standing;
· consideration will be given to possible emergency credit limit increases; and
· no prepayment charges will be imposed on early access to term deposits for one month.
· Westpac has announced that:
· affected home loan customers may apply to suspend repayments for three months;
· credit card customers may ask to defer their next credit card payment and request an emergency credit limit increase;
· no early withdrawal penalties will be imposed for customers wishing to withdraw term and farm management deposits;
· principal and interest repayments on term loans will be deferred for 12 months; and
· carry on finance will be made available to viable farms.
· NAB has announced that:
· flexibility will be applied in restructuring loan arrangements to absorb interest charges and provide carry on finance;
· existing business loan customers can apply for loan repayments to be deferred and their facilities restructured; and
· farmers who receive Government support will not be charged for application fees on restructured facilities.
